This will be her 2nd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah L. is from the barangay (village) of Sta. Cruz, Tangub City. She is 27 years old, is married, and has two infant children. Leah owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products such as candies, some food for snacks, coffee, diapers, etc., in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Leah joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Leah is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica E. is from the barangay (village) of Sta. Cruz, Tangub City. She is 42 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Monica owns and operates a business raising chickens for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Monica joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. Monica is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Nicanora

texts.en:
Nicanora A. is from the barangay (village) of Sta. Cruz, Tangub City. She is 48 years old, is widowed, and has three adult children. Nicanora owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Nicanora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Nicanora is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena S., a 35-year-old member of ASHI, hopes to pursue the education of her four children (aged from 2 to 13 years old) until they earn a college degree which she believes to be the key to unlocking a better kind of life.

Rowena, herself, has not reached a higher level of education due to poverty and, because of that, offices would not consider employing her over the other college degree holders. She didn’t even have a chance to obtain any loans before ASHI came and so didn’t have the opportunity to venture in a business. With that, she felt how hard life can be at times, especially when she had her own family and children to sustain.

Rowena and her husband, who is a farmer, have been working so hard to earn money to support the needs of their children. They were both very happy when they found out about ASHI. Rowena became a member in 2009 and, from that year, she has able to gain the confidence and determination to grow and sustain their rice and vegetable farming business. From this is anchored the enrichment of her hopes for her children.

Since Rowena and her husband’s farmland is acquired through arriendo, which is a Spanish term commonly used in the province referring to land rental (farmland is rented and the owner is paid with part of the harvest), they both hope to have a larger amount of business capital to be able to gain more.

Also, as much as possible through loans they can borrow through ASHI, they would like to stop using the alili system (a common system farmers use to acquire capital). The alili system is a system whereby farmers obtain money from wealthy people in exchange for part of their harvest. With this system, farmers gain only a very small profit.

loans.use: To purchase necessary farm inputs such as rice seedlings, fertilizer and to pay for equipment rental

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet L., 28, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Rowel L., a vendor, and they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Janet has been managing her own balut business for the past few years (a balut is a native Filipino delicacy consisting of a fertilized duck egg with a nearly-developed embryo inside that is boiled and sold as a night snack).

Janet has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her balut business.

To ensure the success of her business, Janet would like to apply for a PHP 19,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more of her products to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

Janet dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also dreams of having her own house and lot someday.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more of her products to be incorporated into her current inventory

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna B., 35, is from Sta Cruz, Tangub city. She is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products such as shampoo, candies, soap for laundry and in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Myrna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Myrna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Jenalin

texts.en:
Jenalin G., 27, wants to make sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Jenalin is married to Roel G.. She has been supplementing her husband's income by managing her own ice-cream business for the past few years.

Jenalin has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She has been consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her ice-cream business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as additional capital for buying equipment and raw ingredients needed to continue the production and supply of ice-cream.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also dreams of having her own house and a land someday.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying equipment and raw ingredients for ice-cream production and supply

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora V. is 36 years old and is a mother of six children, aged between one and 13 years. Despite being poor, Nora is happy that all her family members enjoy a harmonious relationship. She, at times, feels unfortunate for not being well-off and not being able to offer the best of lifestyle for her children. However, she is happy that she has a very supportive husband and loving children that make her feel luckier than many wealthy people who are faced with family problems and factions.

According to Nora, education is the greatest asset she can leave behind for her children when she grows old. She dreams of graduating her children from college, and she believes that nobody can take away the wealth of education. Nora is requesting a loan from ASHI to make her fishing business, in partnership with her husband, stable and profitable. She will use the loan amount to purchase fishing gears and fish, in addition to their own catch, for selling.

Nora says that the money earned from this business will help her children get their college degrees and give them a better lifestyle. She wants to pass on the virtues of good moral character and core values that she has learned from friends and other members of ASHI to her children, so that they are better prepared to face struggles in their lives.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gears and fish, aside from their own catch, for selling

loans.name: Ponciana

texts.en:
Ponciana P. is from Sta Cruz, Tangub City. She is 60 years old and married. To make a living, Ponciana owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general alteration & tailoring services to local community members. Ponciana has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ponciana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ponciana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Ponciana is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Ponciana from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her tailoring business

loans.name: Carlota

texts.en:
Carlota S. is from Sta Cruz, Tangub City. She is 33 years old and single. To make a living, Carlota owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products such as rice, shampoo, candies sugar, salt, etc. in the local community. Carlota has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Carlota joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlota has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Carlota is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Carlota from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en: Mrs. Chantha Y. sells dessert at her house in the village; her husband, Mr. Sros Soeung, is a farmer. They have been married since 1993 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. The family lives in a Phnom Penh suburb. Chantha has applied for a Kiva loan twice already (see here and here). Her second loan was used to purchase a motorbike for commuting. She now is asking for $1,000 as her third loan to buy another motorbike for her son to launch a motor taxi business. Chantha will also use a part of her loan to connect her house to a private electricity utility service.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her son to drive as a motor taxi and to connect her house to an electricity supply

loans.name: Lang

texts.en:
Mrs. Lang C., age 43, and her husband, Mr. Thy Sdoeng, age 43, have been married for twenty-one years and have five children: four sons and one daughter. The family lives along National Road Number Five approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Lang has been selling lotus for fifteen years and her husband has been a fisherman since he was single. Lang wants to supplement her income by starting a pig-raising business, so she is applying for a $500 loan to buy piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Thary

texts.en:
Mrs. Thary N. and her husband, Mr. Heng Siv, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1986 and have four children.

Thary has been selling fruit (water melons, apples, oranges, etc.) for two years. She buys them in Phnom Penh for resale at the village market. Her husband, Mr. Heng Siv, has been a village doctor since 1984.

Thary does not have enough capital to purchase more fruit for resale so she is requesting a loan of $1,000 to help her capital.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothing for ladies, gentlemen, children, cosmetics, sheet sets and other things

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann N.’s aspiration in life is to see her children living a comfortable kind of life in the future with their own families. That is why, now that they are still young (their ages range are from 8 months to 12 years), she and her fisherman husband try to sustain their small business and continue to work hard growing it, hoping that one day it will become stable and profitable.

Mary Ann, being the one in charge of the family cash flow and budget, sees to it that food and education are always the priority among other expenses. Though it was easy for her to do that, she also wants to provide her children with nice clothing and other things. Yet, for now, she has to focus on her desire to strengthen their foundation through a good quality of education that they can obtain from school until they graduate from college. Then they will be able to have more opportunities to enhance their own lives someday.

Nevertheless, Mary Ann also believes that, in partnership with her husband, one day their fishing and fish-selling business will grow through the loans she can obtain through ASHI, being one of its members. Then, through their business proceeds, she would have money to buy nice things for her children and that would at least inspire them to study harder and maintain a good performance at school.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and a fishing boat to increase the volume of their catch

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeun T. and her husband, Mr. Khom Moun, have been married since 1972 and have seven children: three sons and four daughters. They live on an island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sokhoeun has been a silk weaver since she was fifteen years old. Her husband is a construction worker and rice farmer. Sokhoeun is applying for a $600 loan to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en: Mrs. Vanna N., age 36, and her husband, Mr. Mov Say, age 38, have been married since 1992 and have three children: one son and two daughters, all of them are in school. Vanna and her husband are silk weavers. They sell their finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Because the silk weaving business is their main source of income, Vanna is asking for another loan (see previous loans here and here) in the amount of $600 to purchase silk materials for continuing her business. In the photo, Mrs. Vanna is not shown with her loom because the loom was set up inside her house.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for continuing her silk weaving business

loans.name: Hot

texts.en:
Mr. Hot R. is a humble villager living in a rural area of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. He is a domestic house constructor who has been working in this sector since he was single. Now he is married with a lovely young kid who depends on his income. His wife stays at home to care for the kid and also works on the field by growing rice and vegetable crops to sell for a profit.

In the past, not having their own animal, Hot R.’s wife always hired a neighbor’s cow to help plow their farmland. Hot R. now hopes to reduce this fee by asking for a loan to purchase an ox. With any remaining cash from the loan, he will buy fertilizer to fatten the crops.

loans.use: To purchase an ox for plowing

loans.name: Much

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is an older woman and the mother of six children, three of whom are now married and live independently, while the other three are single. Her husband is a local crop farmer.

S. owns a small store along the street where she sells cool coconut to passersby. She will be using this loan as capital to use towards purchasing more coconuts to resell.

loans.use: To use towards purchasing more coconuts to sell

loans.name: Chhoem

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhoem S., age 48, makes a living by selling fish. She sells the fish that her husband gives her or that she buys from other fisherman. She currently earns an average of US$5 a day, and she has been running her business for several years. Her husband is 46 years old and is a fisherman who works along a local river.

Chhoem S. is the mother of six teenage children who are no longer in school. Two are married and live separately; the others are unmarried and they each contribute some of their incomes to help the family meet its daily expenses.

Because she doesn’t have her own vehicle to transport the fish to sell at the market, Chhoem S. is applying for a loan to buy a secondhand motorcycle and to buy more tools for fishing.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorcycle to transport her fish and to buy more fishing equipment for her husband

loans.name: Rahmat's Group

texts.en:
Rahmat lives in a small city called Vehari, which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. Her husband’s name is A. S. and he owns a scrap shop in the market. She has a son who helps his father in his scrap business.

Rehmat is a very supportive lady. She helps her family financially with her domestic-sewing business. Her clientele base is her neighbors. She receives order from them and earns reasonable charges.

Rehmat is applying for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to buy more scrap material for his business. She is very sure that by making an investment in her husband’s business, he will be able to increase his income which will be used to enhance her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To enable her husband to purchase more scrap for his scrap business

loans.name: Mr. Tha Aom Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mr. Tha A. was born in 1972. He is the village bank president who has been selected by 13 people who live in Preaek Louk village in Kandal province. All these members make up a village bank loan and they will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to increase their income to support their families. Mr. Tha A. sells recyclable items and earns a little money to support his family because he has only a little capital to invest his business. So to improve his business, Mr. Tha A. is seeking a loan to buy more recyclables to resell. His wife, Mrs. Sen Beng, is a seamstress in a garment factory. With these activities, they support three children. One child is a seamstress in a garment factory, another is a student in the local public school, and the youngest one is five years old.

loans.use: To buy more recyclables to sell

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios C., 55, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She finds comfort in her children. She makes sure that she earns enough for the six children still living with her so that they can have a better life.  She has been managing her variety store while operating a rug-making business.

Remedios has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 49,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries and beverages for her variety store. She will also use some of the loan to purchase more products to be incorporated into her current store inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can leave a successful business as a legacy to them.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying groceries, toiletries and beverages etc. for her variety store

loans.name: Chhut

texts.en:
Mrs. H. is 46 years of age and lives in a village located in the rural area of Siem Reap province. She weaves thatch to sell to earn her living. The product is used to cover houses. 

H. has been depending on the income from her husband’s job fishing along the river. The couple has two single children, while another three are now married. H. is taking out her first loan in order to buy extra materials for their fishing operation.

loans.use: To buy extra materials for fishing operation.

loans.name: Marinet

texts.en:
Marinet is a 40-year-old woman who has been buying & selling different small goods in the province of Antipolo, Rizal. She started the business 6 years ago to help her family meet their basic needs as everything is very expensive and her husband’s salary wasn’t enough to sustain their daily expenditures. For this reason, she joined Kiva partner ASHI (means “To rise up from Poverty”) in 2005, and felt very glad to access secured working capital and peer support to achieve her dreams in life.

Now, Marinet continues to run her business to generate income and financially support her family. Marinet's weekly income is about 3,000 PHP and she would like to increase it to 4,000Php. With this motivation, she applied for new loan of 40,000 Php to purchase more merchandise for her business and increase her working capital. Marinet has already had previous loans from ASHI and repaid them successfully, therefore she is being entrusted with a much larger loan. An active businesswoman, Marinet is also engaged in a sewing business for added income.

Marinet has been dedicating herself to expanding her business in order to support her dreams for her family to have a decent way of life. She will be very responsible with her obligations and she is thankful to the people who support the loan she is requesting, which will be very helpful to make her business grow further so that her son can fulfill his dreams of completing his college degree and finding a stable job.
.

loans.use: To increase her working capital and purchase more merchandise for her business

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
This is Miriam F., 48, resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Reynaldo Figueroa, a businessman, and mother of five children, one of whom is not going to school yet. By the grace of God, Miriam has managed to support her older children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to send her children to school until they are in college. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Miriam, as she herself was a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children.

Miriam operates a variety store while overseeing operations of their tricycle. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Miriam earns her income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and reselling at a piece rate. 

Meanwhile, her tricycle, a sidecar attached to a motorcycle which is used as transportation between narrow streets and off the highways, is being operated by her husband. Miriam’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers in her store and for her tricycle are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Miriam dreams of being able to give all her children a good, high quality education through her hard work in her business. She also hopes to save part of her income to use for future expansion of her business.

loans.use: buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
A hard-working entrepreneur, Evelyn has run a busines buying and selling frozen foods for almost five years from Antipolo in the province of Rizal, earning a reasonable weekly profit. Evelyn’s main challenge has been having a small stock due to the hindrances of small working capital to put into her frozen foods venture. 

In 2005, she joined ASHI, a Kiva partner in the Philippines, and is very grateful for secured access to capital and other services such as savings and insurance. This loan amounting 30,000 Php is to help Evelyn buy frozen food products to increase her stock to match her customers’ demands in the local area. She thinks that commercializing her business and expanding it will enable her to earn more revenue and be able to pay school fees for her three children and cater for other family needs. With access to additional working capital from Kiva supporters, Evelyn is hopeful her dreams of sending her children to a university to complete college degrees will be achieved. Evelyn’s wishes to give her children a brighter future fuel her dedication to her business.

loans.use: To buy frozen food products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more products to incorporate into her current inventory

loans.name: Hot

texts.en:
Mrs. Hot Y. has been in the farming business for years. She plants various crops to earn a living as well as raises a few pigs, and typically generates an income of $2 per day. Her husband operates a taxi service and fishes as well.

This couple has been married for years and has four children. One of the children is married and three are teenagers going to school or work.

Hot Y. finds it hard traveling anywhere because she doesn’t have her own vehicle. She has dreamed of having a vehicle for a long time but she doesn’t have the money to buy one. So, she has decided to seek a Kiva loan to be used to buy an old motorbike to provide transportation for her family. She will also use this motorcycle to transport her mature crops to the market.

loans.use: To buy an old motorbike for family transportation and to take her crops to the market

loans.name: Thavy's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four members who have selected Mrs. Thavy S. as the group leader. They are all villagers in Khpob Veaeng village, Kandal province. All the members will use their portion of their loan for varied activities to support their businesses. Mrs. Thavy S. is 33 years old. Right now her business is selling fruits in the local market where she can earn only a little money because she does not have enough capital. So to improve this business, Mrs. Thavy S. is seeking a loan to buy more fruits to resell. Her husband, Mr. Porlla York, is a driver for a private company where he earns a low salary to support his family, too. With these activities, they support a child who is too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more fruits to resell

loans.name: Sokha's Group

texts.en: The five people in this group loan are villagers in Spean Daek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sokha K. is the group leader, selected by the other members. The members will use their portion of the loan in various ways. She and her husband, Mr. Sokha Leng, are farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land to grow crops to earn some money to support their family. But now they have a problem because their field is far away from an irrigation system. So to solve this problem, Mrs. Sokha K. is requesting a loan to buy a pump machine. This couple has six children, all of whom are studying in local public school and help their parents to do farming.

loans.use: To buy a pump machine

loans.name: Kham

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is 44 years old and is a resident of Battambang Province where she earns a living raising poultry in a cage next to her house. She raises ducks, chickens, other birds and pigs to produce eggs and young ones. She also sells her cattle to a buyer when they come to maturity.

S. is married with two kids who are unmarried and live at home. Her husband’s name is Horm Pov and he is skilled in carving traditional statues.

S. says that their current income is not enough to serve them and she hopes to invest in a new business. Because she doesn’t have the capital, she decided to apply for a $500 loan to be used to purchase a cart, a juice machine, and other essential equipment that she will use to squeeze sugarcane to produce juice to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a cart, a juice machine, and other essential equipment

loans.name: Mrs. Sokoeun Sam Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Preaek Thmei village in Kandal province, there is a location that has 14 people who make up a village bank loan. Mrs. Sokoeun S. is the village bank president, selected by the other members who will use their loan for various goals. She is 46-year-old. She owns a general store in the local village where she can resell groceries to support her family. One the side, she is also a flower seller in the local market. Since her selling flower is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Sokoeun S. is seeking a loan to buy more flowers to sell. Her husband, Mr. Roeurn Run, is a policeman who earns a low salary to support his family too. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a  garment factory, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more flowers to resell

loans.name: Ramzana's Group

texts.en:
Ramzana is the wife of M. A. and resides in a city called Vehari in Pakistan. She is an uneducated lady, who couldn’t get an education due to the poor financial conditions of her family. She owns a small house with two rooms in an area of Vehari known as Liaqat Park. 

Her husband operates a business selling medicines. He supplies medicines to different medical stores and to clinics as well. He has seven years of experience in this business.  

Ramzana also helps him financially by operating a domestic-sewing business. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. 
She is applying for a loan from Asasah to invest the loan amount in her husband’s business. With the loan amount her husband will be able to buy medicines in bulk and earn a good profit on them.

loans.use: Purchase medicines in bulk to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy firewood, rice, sugar, and beans

loans.name: Mrs. Suosdei Meoung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 19 people who live in Kaoh Krabei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Suosdei M. is the village bank president selected by the other members, who will use their loan in different ways. She is 50 years old. She is a flower and banana seller in the local market, where she earns little money to support her family because she does not have enough capital to invest. So to improve this business, Mrs. Suosdei M. is asking for a loan to buy more bananas to resell. 

Her husband, Mr. Saroeurn Dy, is a chef. She is the mother of seven children, four of whom are chefs and help her to sell flowers and bananas, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy makeup, cremes, perfumes, shampoo, makeup bags etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy firewood, cooking oil, potatoes, cocoa, sugar, soy meat, barley in grains, soft drinks, gatorade, bags, etc.

loans.name: Mrs. Pov Me Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov M., born in 1965, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice – not to sell, but for her family. Aside from this, she is also a pig breeder, while her husband, Mr. Sophorl Chea, is a lumberjack. Now she has a problem because her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Pov M. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will buy gasoline and piglets, and rent a plow machine to plow her field. She is the mother of seven children: two are seamstresses in a garment factory, while another is helping the father do business, and the others are attending the local public school.

Eleven people make up this village bank and live in An Long Barang village in Kandal province. Mrs. Pov M. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. The members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy corn, firewood, lime, and ceramic hotplates.

loans.name: Lai's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lai T. was born in 1950 and she is the group leader who has been selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Nub N., are farmers who own a 1.5 hectare plot of land so they can earn a little money to support their family. They want to expand their farm to increase the crop yield this year. So, to reach this goal, Mrs. Lai T. is applying for a loan to rent a piece of land for farming. With the rest of the loan she will buy rice seed and rent a plow machine to plow her field. She is the mother of two children: one is a waiter, while the other one is attending the local public school.

This group has four members who live in Preak Me Srok village in Kandal province. They will use their portions of the loan in various ways to improve their businesses.

loans.use: To rent a piece of land to do farming

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en: Beverly L. is a married woman who lives in Purok 3, Brgy. Linaon, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She earns a living by operating three business ventures: running a general store, farming and making rice cakes. Her husband Patricio, who is 42 years old, works as a farmer to earn a living. Beverly joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Beverly has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 14,000, thus, lifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan cycle, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to buy additional stock for her general store so that she could continue to save up for the future. Beverly L. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Vanny's Group

texts.en:
This four member group loan, led by Mrs. Vanny K., is based in Preaek Ph'av village in Kandal province. All the members will use their loan for different purposes. 


Mrs. Vanny K. sells sweet potato grill, door to door. Her husband, Mr. Chhat Sambo, is a construction worker. She has a problem in that her cart, which she uses in her business, is broken. To solve this, and to improve her business, Mrs. Vanny K. is applying for a loan to fix her cart. 


She is the mother of four children. One of them is a seamstress in a garment factory; two are enrolled in the local public school and help their parents’ businesses, and the youngest one is two years old.

loans.use: To fix her cart

loans.name: Tom's Group

texts.en:
This five person group loan, led by Mrs. Tom S., is based in Leuk D. village, Kandal province. Each member will use their portion of the loan in different ways to improve their current living standards. 


Mrs. Tom S. is 38 years old and is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Khlok Srun, is a construction worker and also a fisherman who earns some money to support his family. This couple has a problem in that their fishing supplies are too old to use. Mrs. Tom S. is requesting a loan to buy new fishing supplies to improve their business. 


They support two children who both study at the local public school and also support their father’s business.

loans.use: To buy fishing supplies

loans.name: Suy's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Suy S. is the group leader of a four member group loan located in Preaek Traeng village in Kandal province. They will all use their portion of the loan in different ways to improve their businesses. 


Mr.  Suy S. is 46 years old. He is a laborer while his wife, Mrs. Sophors Sun, is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Through this activity, the couple supports seven children. One of their children is a seamstress in a garment factory; another is a jewelry maker; four are attending the local public school, and the youngest one is three years old. Although all the members try to work hard, they can only earn a small amount of money. To improve the family's living conditions, Mr. Suy S. is asking for a loan to buy coffee and fruit to start a new business reselling these goods.

loans.use: To buy coffee and fruit for resale

loans.name: Azimjon

texts.ru: Гафуров Азимчон проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 26 лет. Холост. Образование среднее. Живет вместе с матерью. Имеет небольшую мастерскую, где ремонтирует машины и занимается вулканизацией. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 2 года. Кредит берет для приобретения запасных частей и необходимых оборудований.
texts.en:
Azimjon G. lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube. He is 26 years old and single. He has a high school education. He lives with his mother. He has a small workshop where he repairs cars and patches tires with hot vulcanization. He has been doing this for two years. He is taking out a loan to acquire spare parts and necessary equipment.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Acquiring necessary equipment

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase high-quality cosmetics and furniture for her salon

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty C. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 50 years old. Betty is single. To make a living, Betty owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Betty joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Betty is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Betty from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a new motor for his taxi

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase a ticket to Russia for her daughter

loans.name: Chu

texts.en:
Chu  Thị H. (20201030044) is a 30-year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To make a living, Chu  owns & operates a cloth business.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing new cloth to local community members.  Chu  has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2009, Chu  joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Chu  has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.  Chu  is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.  This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  Chu  plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Chu  Thị H. (20201030044) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, Chu  Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh quần áo.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ quần áo mới cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Chu  thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Chu  kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2009, Chu  đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Chu  đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thêm hàng hóa tồn kho & vốn lưu động.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua thêm hàng hóa tồn kho & vốn lưu động.  Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  Chu  dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Jecelyn

texts.en:
Jecelyn R. is from the village of San Roque, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old. Jecelyn is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Jecelyn owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products,  and she also wants to invest some of the money in installing a mini-eatery in the local community. Jecelyn is just starting this business.

In 2008, Jecelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jecelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Jecelyn is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Jecelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase sewing materials such as thread, small- and big-sized scissors, and so on

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
Huệ Nguyễn Thị (20203020058) is a 52-year-old woman living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Huệ is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Đông Thái nhóm 11 (Nhóm 11).


Huệ is married and has 2 adult children.  To make a living, Huệ owns & operates a business venture making & selling food.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community.  Huệ has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


Huệ joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.      She is now requesting a loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  Huệ plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Cao Thị H. (0) is a 28-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business operating a service-based business.


2.  Nguyễn Thị H. (0) is a 30-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her manufacturing business.


3.  Trương Thị B. (0) is a 47year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food.


4.  Tô Thị T. (0) is a 46-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Huệ Nguyễn Thị (20203020058) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Huệ là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Đông Thái nhóm 11 (Nhóm 11).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các pH. thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán thức ăn nhanh & những loại thực phẩm cao cấp khác trong cộng đồng địa pH..  Huệ thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Huệ kiếm được khoảng 4.000.000 VND.  Huệ đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  0    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Cao Thị H. (0) là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


2.  Nguyễn Thị H. (0) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất.


3.  Trương Thị B. (0) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


4.  Tô Thị T. (0) là 46 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en: N. Nguyễn Thị (20201030053) is a 38-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. N. is the group leader of this seven-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Phố Chờ 2 nhóm 10 (Nhóm 10). N. is married and has four school-aged children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling bicycles in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over eleven years and earns approximately 3,700,000 VND a month. N. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. The loan will be her first from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. Nguyễn Thị Thế (0) is a 25-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her butcher shop. 2. Nguyễn Thị Tư (0) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food. 3. Nguyễn Thị T. (0) is a 23-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store. 4. Đặng Thị T. (0) is a 30-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her tailoring business. 5. Nghiêm Thị L. (0) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her service-based business. 6. Bùi Thị H. (0) is a 33-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** N. Nguyễn Thị (20201030053) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. N. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Phố Chờ 2 nhóm 10 (Nhóm 10). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán xe đạp trong cộng đồng địa phương. N. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 11 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, N. kiếm được khoảng 3.700.000 VND. N. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể T. cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. 0 Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Nguyễn Thị Thế (0) là 25 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng T.t. 2. Nguyễn Thị Tư (0) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 3. Nguyễn Thị T. (0) là 23 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 4. Đặng Thị T. (0) là 30 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc. 5. Nghiêm Thị L. (0) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 6. Bùi Thị H. (0) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ T. tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen lives in the historic city called Lahore which is famous for its gardens and its culture in all of Pakistan. She is the mother of five children: four sons and a daughter.  

None of them were able to get their education due to poor financial conditions, but now things are a bit different because three of her sons have started doing work to support the family. Two of them make shoes and other is involved in Punjabi food-selling business. 

Parveen has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who sells fruit in the fruit market.  With the loan amount, he will buy fruit in bulk which will help him make more income as the result of the availability of more stock and more fruit variety.  

Parveen hopes that with the help of increased profit she will be able to send her youngest son to school as he is still just 7 years of age, and her family's financial problems will be solved.

loans.use: Purchase fruit for resale

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị (20213030050) is a 25-year-old woman living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  L. is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Cầu Gạo 2 (Nhóm 11).


L. is single and does not have any children.  To making a living, L. owns & operates a general store business venture.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community.  L. has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Tô V. C. (0) is a 46-year-old man who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support his business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Trần Thị T. (0) is a 56-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her clothing business.


3.  Đinh Thị Hà (0) is a 28-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Mặc dù mỗi tH.nh viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các tH.nh viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Tô V. C. (0) là 46 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Trần Thị T. (0) là 56 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận H.nh công việc kinh doanh quần áo.


3.  Đinh Thị Hà (0) là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa H.ng bách hóa.


Về SEDA:

Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Togtohhorol

texts.en:
Togtohhorol D. is 34 years old and lives with his wife, son and daughter in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His son is a local middle school student and the daughter goes to a kindergarten, while his wife works with him. 

Togtohhorol currently operates three separate businesses in his town with the help of his wife. Their businesses include a cafeteria and food sales and a transportation service. Togtohhorol spends most of his time managing the cafe during the summertime and works at the transportation and meat sales businesses in winter. The couple started all of their businesses in 2002 after Togtohhorol had a car accident and was injured in 2001. They have found success in all three ventures and have a strong customer base throughout their community. 

For the future, the couple is planning to expand their cafeteria. Togtohhorol is requesting a 2,300,000 MNT loan to purchase a variety of food products, meal ingredients for his business, in order to increase their working capital.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Batdorj

texts.en:
Batdorj S. is 39 years old and  lives with his wife and two children in Uvurhangai province, central Mongolia.  He and his family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two children attend a local middle school while his wife is a homemaker. 

Batdorj owns and operates his own wooden product business, specializing in 'ger' parts, 'ger' furniture, and other larger furniture pieces. His business is quite family-oriented as he operates his business with the help of his brother. He started his business in 2005. Most of his profit come from the sales of his larger-sized furniture which are sold at prices between 40000 to 150000 MNT. All of his products are made with great care and attention to detail which has earned him a reputation among his customers as a quality furniture provider. 

Batdorj would like to expand his sales so that he can increase his working capital.  He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood so that he can increase the number and variety of large furniture pieces that he can sell.

loans.use: purchase wood for his business

loans.name: Bayardulam

texts.en:
Bayardulam B. is 43 years old and lives with her two daughters in Uvs province, western Mongolia. She and her family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Bayardulam operates a transport service in her town. She uses a car  to transport people back and forth around her town. 

Bayardulam started her transportation business in 2008 after purchasing her car. She has found success with her business and has gained much experience as a driver over the years. 

Bayardulam is a very honest and hard-working person. For the future she hopes to continue to provide a high-quality, convenient and efficient transportation service.  She is requesting a 400,000 MNT loan to purchase new parts for her car in order to increase her earnings so she will be able to afford her daughters' tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Mrs. Thut Nut Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight members make up this village bank loan based in Preaek Pring village in Kandal province. Mrs. Thut N. is a village bank president, selected by the other members who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 


Mrs. Thut N. owns a general store in the local village where she sells groceries. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. To achieve this goal, Mrs. Thut N. is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. 


She is a widow with two children, one of whom is a chef, while the other is a tailor at home.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for resale

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en: Ainura B. is the leader of this group. She is 32 and married. She has two daughters; both of them study at school. Ainura owns a shop where she sells convenience goods, and her husband works as a taxi-driver. Ainura and her husband also breed cattle to make more money. They have been in the business for twelve years. They sell animals after fattening them at a higher price. Ainura makes 10,000 soms per month. With money received from this loan, she wants to purchase five sheep for breeding (one sheep costs 3,000 soms). Archagul E., 42, is married. She has a daughter and two sons. The daughter studies at university and the sons are at school. Six years ago, with an initial investment of 2000 soms, Archagul began to sew Kyrgyz national cloth and dressmaking supplies. In this way, she makes 3,000 soms per month. Archagul applied for a loan because she needs money to pay for her husband’s medical services (he is a handicapped person). Saparbek A., 31, is married. A year ago, with an initial investment of 20,000 soms, he started to sell convenience goods in his village. In this way, he makes 10,000 soms per month. The profit made it possible for him to purchase a vehicle. And now Saparbek has applied for a loan because he needs money to purchase building materials to start repairing his house. In the future, he plans to find a permanent job with a high salary. Aida A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 46 and married. She has a daughter and two sons. The daughter is married and works as a nurse. The first son studies at university and the second is at school. Aida’s husband is an artist (he prepares monuments) and she helps him with that activity. With money received from the loan, Aida wants to purchase materials which are needed for making monuments. In the future, she plans to build a house in Bishkek. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase five sheep for breeding

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine L. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 25 years old. Catherine is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Catherine owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from gathering and selling seaweeds at the market. The business existed for more than 20 years already handed down to her from her father.

Catherine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Catherine has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Catherine is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Boldsaihan

texts.en: Boldsaihan S. is 21 years old and lives with his parents in Hovd province, in western Mongolia. He and his family live in their own house. His father works as an engineer in a local meteorology center, while his mother sells household products at a local market. He started his PC game business in 2009 in the basement of an apartment with eight new personal computers. His daily earnings now exceed 30,000 to 50,000 MNT. Boldsaihan is a modest and hard-working man who is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 MNT to purchase a car for his family.

loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Phally's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has four members who live in Preaek Reang village in Kandal province. They will each use their portion of the loan in different ways to improve their businesses. 


Mrs. Phally T. is the group leader, selected by the other members. She owns a general store at the local village where she can earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. Mrs. Phally T. is, therefore, asking for a loan to buy more groceries for resale. 


She is a widow with four children: one of them is a security guard, one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resale

loans.name: Conrado

texts.en:
Conrado R. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 39 years old. Conrado is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Conrado owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. He also owns a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife manages. They sell basic food and daily-use products.

Conrado joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Conrado has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Conrado is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to raise. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Conrado from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to raise

loans.name: Mrs. Sokha Och Village Bank Group

texts.en:
