This village bank loan has ten people who have been selected. Mrs. Sokha O. is the village bank president, located in Chamkar Ta Ngaet village in Kandal province. All members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Sokha O. was born in 1968 and she is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. Now, she has a problem because her field has infertile soil and it is time to plow, but she does not have enough money to suppor this. So to improve production, Mrs. Sokha O. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and hire a plow machine. She is a widow with two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire a plow machine

loans.name: Saruul-Erdene

texts.en:
Saruul-Erdene D. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and four children, aged between 3 and 19, in Hentiy province, eastern of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a house. His eldest son is disabled, the middle two children attend a local middle school, and the youngest daughter goes to a local kindergarten. 

Saruul-Erdene and his wife work together repairing tires and cars next to their house. The couple owns a car repair service which they began in 2007 and their work is very popular because their work is fast and of high quality. This couple works hard to provide for their children and improve the quality of their lives with education. Saruul-Erdene is a hard-working and creative, modest person that says, " I have been working as a driver for ages and now am glad to repair cars and make the other drivers happy ".  

He is requesting a 1,500,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) loan in order to purchase rubber, tools, equipment and new tires for his car repair business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
Jerry M. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 25 years old. Jerry is married. Jerry owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. 

Jerry joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Jerry is requesting a new loan of 6000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to expand the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand the business

loans.name: Lauriana

texts.en:
Lauriana S. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 57 years old. Lauriana is widowed and has seven adult children. Lauriana owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lauriana has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

Lauriana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Lauriana has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lauriana is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ma. Chona

texts.en:
Ma. Chona B. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 41 years old. Ma. Chona is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Chona owns & operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from catching and selling shrimp, crabs and assorted fish at the market. Ma. Chona has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

Ma. Chona joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Ma. Chona is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income and pay for her children's school fees.

“Asenso Loans are a new product offered by CEVI for clients showing strong performance in previous loans, and who need a larger loan in order to continue to develop. CEVI recognises the importance of helping people out of poverty, as well as providing continuous support and training as these clients progress. 

CEVI aims to provide financial services, not only our poorest clients, but also to our developing clients who should be rewarded for the way in which they display promising business skills. Please help us provide support for these clients”

loans.use: to expand the business

loans.name: Sughran

texts.en:
Sughran belongs to a historic city of Lahore Pakistan which is famous for its food and culture. She is the mother of two children and her husband sells milk to earn an income. Sughran bibi is a housewife but she also helps her husband and takes care of her cattle. 

She is applying for a loan from Asasah for her husband because he wants to buy a buffalo to increase the production of milk. With the help of another buffalo, her husband will be able to supply more milk and able to fulfill more orders. This will ultimately increase their household income.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Phavy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phavy C. is a group leader who has been selected by four group members who live in Chong Kaoh-I village in Kandal province. All the group members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 


Mrs. Phavy C. is 41 years old. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. She faces an obstacle in that her field is infertile. So, to improve production, Mrs. Phavy C. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. 


She is a widow with six children, three of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Ma. Lina

texts.en:
Ma. Lina D. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 42 years old. Ma. Lina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Lina owns & operates a fishing business, buying and reselling assorted fish to the market. She also dries fish and sells around their community.

In 2009, Ma. Lina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Lina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Lina is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to raise. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Ma. Lina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Seam

texts.en:
Mrs. Seam B. is a villager in Kaoh Reah Leu village in Kandal province. She was born in 1949. She is a farmer who rents a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support her family. She currently has a problem in that she does not have money to farm. To solve this problem, Mrs. Seam B. is asking for a loan to rent a plot of land. She will use the rest of the loan to hire farm laborers. 


She is a widow with one child who is a laborer and also a fisherman.

loans.use: To rent a plot of land

loans.name: Hieu's Group

texts.en:
Hieu T. N. is 49 years old. She not only grow rice, but she also raises chickens. Now, she raises about 400 chickens and sells eggs one or twice per week. She has two children. Her husband is a farmer. They have a monthly income of about 5,000,000 Vietnamese dong. She has participated in SEDA since 2004 and repaid punctually. In this loan cycL., she would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND to buy food for chickens.
 
About other borrowers in her group.
 Hien T. L. is 41 years old. She sells fruit in the market. She would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND to expand her business.
 Son T. T. is 36 years old. She has a restaurant (sells coffee, beer). She would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND to invest in her restaurant.
 Hoa T. P. is 27 years old. She would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to expand livestock.

loans.use: to buy food for chickens.

loans.name: Ma. Lorena

texts.en:
Ma. Lorena P. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 35 years old. Ma. Lorena is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Lorena owns & operates a fishing business, operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. 

Ma. Lorena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Lorena has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Lorena is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Ma. Lorena from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's school fees and to make improvements to her house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle A. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 21 years old. Michelle is married and has a 5-year-old child. To make a living, Michelle owns & operates a fishing business, operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. Michelle has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.

Michelle joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Michelle has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Michelle is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Michelle from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita A., photographed with her grandchild, is from the town of Trinidad. She is 55 years old and married. She has five children and the younger ones still go to school. To make a living, Pacita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Pacita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years now.

Pacita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Pacita has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Pacita is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Pacita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Shamim Akhtar

texts.en:
Shamim akhtar lives in Lahore, which is famous for its historical places and for Punjabi foods. She has given birth to two children. Her daughter is studying and her son is an electrician. Her husband is involved in the business of renting bikes. He lets out motor bikes on rent for specific periods of time to earn money. Shamim has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband, who wants to buy a new motor bike to expand his business. Shamim herself operates a clothes-selling business. She purchases clothes from the famous markets of Lahore, named “Ichara” and “Anarkali”, and sells them to members of her community on good profit. 

Shamim hopes that a new motor bike will be a good addition to her husband’s business and it will increase his income to a good extent.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike for 'rent a bike' business.

loans.name: Wellineth

texts.en:
Wellineth P. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 38 years old. Wellineth is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Wellineth owns & operates a general store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Wellineth has been engaged in her business for over 3 years now.

Wellineth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Wellineth has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Wellineth is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Wellineth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's school fees and to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Yvonne Giselle

texts.en:
Yvonne Giselle S., photographed with her husband, is from the town of Trinidad. She is 37 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Yvonne is involved in fishing. Her husband operates their fishing boat, catching assorted fish, while she sells all of his catch at the market. She also dries fish sometimes that she also sells to the market. She has been engaged in fishing for more than six years now. One of her wishes in life is to have all her children finish college and be professionals, someday.

Yvonne Giselle joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Yvonne Giselle is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to raise. This will be the first loan taken out by Yvonne Giselle from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to raise.

loans.name: Ma. Elna

texts.en:
Despite the fact that Ma. Elna S.’s two children have their own families now, she and her husband, Ireneo, are always there to support them and their grandchildren. John, and Jessie, Ma. Elna’s children are both high school undergraduates and therefore were not able to get employed for a better paying and stable kinds of jobs. 

By sustaining and growing her salted egg making and selling business, in partnership with her husband, and through the support of ASHI, Ma. Elna is able to have a financial source to support her children and her grandchildren. Her hope to enrich the lifestyle of her children and their family gives her strength and energy to continue her hard work. She requests for a loan so that her business will become sustainable and profitable, thus making her family financially stable. Aside from enjoying her business because of the income it generates, Ma. Elna and her husband are happy for they are able to have a bonding time while making salted eggs. They are also helping each other in selling their products in the market.

loans.use: To purchase large volume of eggs and other ingredients needed to make salted eggs for selling.

loans.name: Mrs. Srorn Port Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people make up this village bank loan located in Koun Chreae village in Kandal province. The group loan is headed by Mrs. Srorn P., a village bank president. All the members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family's living conditions. 


Mrs. Srorn P. is 45 years old and is a Khmer cake maker. She is also a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to supP. her family. She currently faces a problem in that it is time to grow rice but she does not have enough money to do this. She is, therefore, applying for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and to hire a plow. 


She is a widow with two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer, and to hire a plow

loans.name: Mrs. Noeurn Buth Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of twelve people based in Koun Chreae village, Kandal province. It is headed by Mrs. Noeurn B., a village bank president wH. was born in 1982. 


She is a farmer wH. owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ki Tun, is a motorbike taxi driver wH. earns a small amount of money to support his family. They currently have a problem in that her husband’s motorbike is broken and they do not have the money to fix it. Mrs. Noeurn B. is, therefore, seeking a loan to repair her husband’s motorbike. She will use the rest of the loan to hire farm laborers to help with her farming business. She is a widow with two children wH. are both too young to work or study.

loans.use: To repair her husband’s motorbike

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.ru: Рахмонов Чамшед проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 46 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Чамшед занимается торговлей на рынке "Саховат". Он продает фрукты и овощи. Этим видом бизнеса занимается уже 10 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Jamshed R. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 46 years old, married, and has three children. His wife is a housewife. Jamshed works in the Sakhovat market. He sells fruit and vegetables. He has been doing this work for ten years. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Mrs. Sophoan Muong Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoan Muong is a village bank president who has been selected by the ten group members who all live in Trapeang Ta Eak village in Kampong Speu province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. They have taken out a loan as part of AMK’s loan workout program. Each client has an outstanding loan with AMK that they are unable to repay. 


Mrs. Sophoan Muong has three children: one is a taxi driver, the second child is employed in a garment factory and the youngest child is attending school. Her husband is a taxi diver who makes a small income to support the family.

As part of AMK’s workout program, each client is trained to produce a product. The ten members of Sophoan Muong’s group have been trained to produce papers. They have been given a loan to purchase raw material and equipment to create papers, while AMK provides them with materials to produce the goods. Ahkun.org will purchase the goods from the clients and sell them on their website. Profits from the sale will go to the group to further help them pay off their outstanding loans, and the loans of their fellow villagers who are in the same difficult position.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and equipment to create papers.

loans.name: Mrs. Kheng Say Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people make up a village bank loan and they have selected Mrs. Kheng S. as a village president. She is a 38-year-old located in Koun Chreae village in Kandal province. All the members will use their portion of the loan for varied purposes to improve their lives. Mrs. Kheng S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land in which to cultivate rice to support her family, while her husband, Mr. Thol Chor, is a fisherman who can also earn some money to support his family. 

Now she has a problem because her husband’s fishing boat is broken. So to solve this problem, Mrs. Kheng S. is applying for a loan to buy resin for the fishing boat and with the rest of the loan, she'll pay for a motorbike lien. She is the mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while another is attending a local public school and the youngest one is a year old.

loans.use: To buy resin to fix a fishing boat

loans.name: Mrs. Kuoy Vay Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of fourteen people who have been selected. Mrs. Kuoy V., who is 37 years old, is the village bank president located in Koun Chreae village, Kandal province.  Each member will use their portion of the loan in various ways that can improve their lives.

Mrs. Kuoy V. is a farmer who owns a half-hectare of land for cultivating rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Sung Ty, is a construction worker.  Although they do work a lot, they earn little income, so to improve their family's standard of living, Mrs. Kuoy V. is asking for a loan to buy a fishing boat to start a new business and with the rest of the loan she will hire a plowing machine to plow her field. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en: Florencia is a busy entrepreneur who is engaged in dual businesses of computer rentals and billiard games in her family's barangay (village). These businesses allow her to save money and to sustain her family’s basic needs. They want to save towards retirement time of their life in the future and have a happy family to live with. Now on her second loan, she has applied for PHP 10,000.00 for the maintenance of her businesses. In the future, Florencia hopes to establish new billiard games and to buy an additional computer machine. Her dreams are to provide a better future for her family and to sustain the profitability of her businesses. Through hard work, Florencia is focused on improving her quality of life through her entrepreneurial initiatives and support from kindhearted Kiva lenders around the world.

loans.use: The loan fund will be used for the maintenance of her businesses.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia S. is a 42-year-old woman and has been a member of ASHI (KIVA's first field partner in the Philippines) for five years. Delia is supporting the financial needs of her two children in high school and she hopes to sustain their education until they graduate from college. Presently, she works hard to give them a better kind of life as much as she can give. Delia feels fortunate that she has able to avail loans through ASHI. The loan enabled her to put up her own business and to generate her own income. The proceeds she gets out of her hog raising and native bag making businesses enables her to augment the small and sporadic income of her hired laborer husband. 

Delia has undergone an operation due to an ovarian tumor. However, her health condition could not alter her desire to make her businesses stable and profitable. For as long as she is a member of ASHI and she can avail loans to be invested in her businesses, she will never lose hope of giving her family a comfortable life and a brighter future. Presently, she can still manage to sell her products and grow her piglets. With the love and support of her family, her outlook in life is always positive.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for bag weaving and a small portion will be used to purchase piglets for her hog raising businesses.

loans.name: Gulbarg

texts.ru: Хошимова Гулбарг проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 41 год. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Имеет большой земельный участок, где сеет пшеницу и овощи. Муж и дети работают вместе с ней. Этим видом деятельности она занимается более 20 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян. Она хочет, посеет и получить хороший урожай.
texts.en:
Gulbarg H. lives in the city of Kulob. She is 41 years old, married, and has five children. She has a high school education. She has a large field where she grows wheat and vegetables. Her husband and children work with her. She has been doing this work for more than twenty years. She wants to take out a loan to buy seed. She wants to sow the seed to reap a good harvest.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying seed

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
44-year-old Josefina L. wants her youngest child to graduate from college and at least have a more comfortable life than her three elder children who are only high school graduates. For financial support to the needs of her children, whose ages range from 14 to 22 years old, especially for the sustainability of education, she is requesting for a loan from KIVA through ASHI. She will be using the loan to enhance her husband’s fishing business as the primary source of income for her family. Her barbeque selling business goes a great deal towards augmenting her husband’s income. , Josefina is selling chicken and pork barbeque, grilled just in front of their house. People passing by are tempted to buy because of the captivating smell. 

For the opportunity for having been a member of ASHI since 2009, Josefina is very glad that she has been entrusted with a loan which has become the main financial source for her family to have a business. Someday, she wishes that her husband’s fishing activity will grow further and will become sustainable. She hopes to sell a large volume of fish from her husband’s catch for bigger amount of profit.

loans.use: Large portion of loan will be used to purchase additional fishing gear and a small portion will be used to purchase ingredients for barbeque.

loans.name: Memuna

texts.en:
Madam Memuna is a simple and active business woman.  She is 39 years old and was born in Kabala, north of Sierra Leone. Her business is located in her home, where she has done her slippers and cosmetic business for the past 15 years. Memuna has a good loan repayment history. Memuna is single and has 3 dependents. She has basic business skills and she works very hard to ensure that her business is profitable. She opens her business to customers at 7:00am and closes at 6:30pm daily.
Her elder sister assisted her with the initial business capital. She started her business with 500,000 Leones. Memuna needs a loan of 3,000,000 Leones for a period of 6 months to help her buy more stock. She intends using the proceeds of her loan to educate her dependents and to provide other basic support to them.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Isata

texts.en:
Isata has traded in local food stuffs for the past four years. She has a good loan repayment track record. She was born in Makeni Town in 1961. Her business is located in her home. She is a well know business women in her community. Isata is married and has 4 children.

Isata completed her secondary school education and then established a business in food items to make her livelihood. Her initial capital was 500,000 Leones which she was able to access from her husband. She is a kind and intelligent trader with good business skills. She needs a loan of 4,000,000 Leones to help her buy more stock.

She intends to use the proceeds of her loan to buy land and to reinvesting in the business.

loans.use: To buy additonal stock of food.

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr: Monsieur Ibrahima N. est  âgé de 39 ans qui exerce du commerce d'équipement sportif dans la période hivernale avec le championnat de football amateur qui regroupe tous les quartiers de la ville de Mbour . Ainsi pour les besoins d'activités de vacances il a créé un restaurant qui va réunir tous les amateurs et supporters d'équipes de football  .A cet effet Monsieur N. sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer ses activités et générer des gains pour sa survie et celle de sa famille surtout durant ces périodes de grandes vacances
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahima N. is 39-years old. He runs a business in the wintertime selling sports equipment for the amateur football championship that involves all the neighborhoods of the city of Mbour. For holiday activities, he opened a restaurant to bring together all the amateurs and fans of the football teams. Mr. N. is requesting a loan to help him strengthen his activities and earn revenue in order to support himself and his family, especially during these vacation periods.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: COMMERCE

loans.name: Ruphina

texts.en:
Ruphina is a very hard working woman with seven children. Since childhood, she has faced many obstacles in life because her parents were poor and could not send her to school after class six of primary school. Instead, she had to go to work on the family farm and help to pay for the education of her younger sibling. Despite this outcome, she cannot read and write. In spite of these limitations, she has set out to overcome poverty and to provide her children with the education she did not have. She also hopes someday to go back to school herself.
 
With these goals in mind, Ruphina joined GHAPE from its inception. So determined she was with her previous loans, which she used to buy land, she has been able to build a house for herself and her children.

With this new loan, she plans to buy one-day chicks, piglets, fowl, feed, pig feed feeders, medication for fowls and pigs and seedlings for her farm. She is contributing 100,000 FRS CFA from her personal savings to the success of this, her project. 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of one day chicks, fowl, pig feed, feeders and seedlings.

loans.name: Elhadji Ibrahima

texts.fr: Monsieur Elhadji Ibrahima B. est un jeune peintre âgé de 25 ans et marié qui exerce des travaux de peintures murales dans la zone de Saly sur commande . Ainsi pour l'acquisition de nouveaux produits il sollicite ce prêt dans le but d'agrandir ses activités . L'artisanat étant une activité importante dans la cité touristique de Mbour Mr B. pourrait faire valoir ses talents d'artistes et générer des bénéfices qui lui permettront de faire face à ses dépenses quotidiennes
texts.en:
Mr. Elhadji Ibrahima B. is a young 25-year old artist, married, who paints commissioned murals in the area of Saly. He is requesting a loan to purchase new painting supplies and expand his activities. Crafts are an important activity in the tourist city of Mbour. Mr. B. plans to showcase his artistic talents and generate profits that would enable him to cover his daily expenses.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase paint

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married and a mother of six children. She has suffered from the death of her father and from the inability to provide enough food and school fees for her family. She went to a private nursing school and has been unemployed.

Motivated by these difficulties, she became a GHAPE member and was trained in business management, marketing techniques, and credit discipline.

She turned to GHAPE to take a loan to invest in her oil mill. She has been very hard working for her farm production. As she says, my farm house is full of harvested crops because of my hard work.

Now she requests a loan of 500000 to buy an oil mill to produce palm oil and to farm more crops.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.

Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase an oil mill.

loans.name: Lum

texts.en:
Born in 1956, Lum J. is married to A. John Awah and they have brought forth five children. A woman who does not like to depend on the husband for all the family needs, and finding it so difficult to accomplish this task, Lum J. joined GHAPE in 1998.

She also has been having marital problems which causes her to be sad all the time but she is appreciative of the fact that she is alive. Her desire is to give her children love and education. She states that she feels better each time she provides something small to her children.

Her inability to get investment capital which could consistently generate income for her to meet her children’s needs is what motivated her to obtain a loan from GHAPE.  With her loan she plans to buy a two-wheel motorcycle. She knows this business will succeed because she is located at a good business site and she is a good rider for the motorcycle.

She plans to use the profits generated to sponsor her children in school and to cater for the basic needs of her family. She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. The first installment repayment shall be done on the fourth month of loan disbursement.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.

Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase a two wheel motorcycle.

loans.name: Ndeye Codou

texts.fr: Mademoiselle Ndeye Codou G. est une jeune commerçante âgée de 20 ans qui vendait des jus de fruits quelle confectionne et quelle revend dans les places publiques et les garages fréquentés . Ainsi pour améliorer ses revenus elle sollicite ce prêt pour acheter des chaussures ,des sacs et des habits pour femmes .Étant orpheline ses revenus seront destinés à soutenir sa mère dans le budget et le fonctionnement de leur maison
texts.en:
Ms Ndeye Codou G. is a young businesswoman who is 20 years old; she used to sell fruit juices, which she made herself and sold in public places and in busy garages. In order to improve her income she is asking for this loan in order to buy shoes, bags and womens' clothing. Since she is without a father, her income will be used to support her mother with the budget and the running of the house.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: COMMERCE

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Born in 1960, Beatrice Sirri is married to Mr Lucas C. and they are blessed with seven children one of which is below the age of 15. She has faced so many challenges as a woman, like when the cold hands of death took her sister away and when she finds it difficult to assist her husband in paying for their children’s education and providing for the basic needs of their children.

The inability to get enough investment capital which would give her higher income to meet her children’s and family's needs motivated her to obtain a loan from GHAPE. She has successfully obtained and repaid loans from GHAPE seven times.

She thinks the business will succeed once she has expanded her farm land and seed trading business. With her loan, she plans to buy seeds and pay for her cultivable land to be cleared. The profit obtained from this investment will assist her husband in paying for their children’s education and basic needs and the rest will be ploughed back into the business.

About GHAPE

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.

Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and clear cultivable land.

loans.name: Ngum

texts.en: Ngum I. is single and has five children. She lives in Azire in Bamenda, North West region of Cameroon. Engulfed with many difficulties, she joined GHAPE in 2005 and since then she has been obtaining loans and paying them back. Her challenges have been poverty and illness, and her children have dropped out of school. She plans to invest this loan in foodstuffs and vegetables, and to cultivate her farm. Irish potatoes, beans, corn and vegetables will cost 125000, 100000, 100000 and 25000 FCFA respectively. She is confident that her business will succeed because she has been in the business for a long time and has numerous customers. The loan will help her community because people will not have to go far to buy what they need. Ngum I. will use the profit to educate her children and for health care. She will also be able to pay her rent without stress. Ngum says loans from GHAPE are very easy to repay and it is for that reason that she chooses GHAPE to obtain her loans. About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multifaceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: For Irish potatoes, beans, corn, vegetables and farming

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is married and has three children. She is an entrepreneur from Kamenka who runs a small business selling food items in the local market. 

Svetlana sells groceries, tea, coffee, and fruit. She owns a nice big vending kiosk with good quality refrigerated coolers and a wide selection of groceries for sale. She has been in this business for ten years. Currently, Svetlana has about 60,000 UAH in turnover capital. Her profit amounts to 7,000-8,000 UAH a month. 

Svetlana is requesting a loan of 16,000 UAH to purchase inventory in bulk. Svetlana’s long-term goal is to open her own little grocery store. She has already purchased land for construction work on it.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Nicolette

texts.en:
Nicolette is a single entrepreneur from Beregovo. Nicolette is an experienced beauty therapist. She owns a beauty salon and offers different face packs and body care service packages. She started her own venture 3 years ago. Nicolette has a loyal clientele who trust her advice and visit her salon on a regular basis. Currently, her gross income is about 5,000 Grivnyas. Net profit amounts to 3,000 Grivnyas a month.   

Nicolette is seeking a loan of 6,500 Grivnyas to purchase various cosmetic sets and supplies for her beauty salon. Additional cosmetic items will help her provide wide-ranging services related to skin health, facial aesthetic, foot care, massages and other services. Nicolette is very serious about her work. She tries to find an individual approach to every customer. Nicolette has repaid all her previous loans without delinquencies.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetic sets

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married and has two grown sons. She is a small-market entrepreneur from Berdyansk. She owns a store where she sells women's outerwear. Valentina knows a lot about customer service. She is always polite with her clients which brings them back to her for shopping. Valentina has been in the trade for 12 years. Presently, she has 12,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. 

Valentina is requesting a loan of 18,000 Grivnyas to diversify the assorted merchandise she offers for sale in her vending kiosk. Valentina buys her inventory in Russia. She travels to wholesalers there to purchase quality clothing items and then offers them at reasonable prices in her home town of Berdyansk. 

Valentina is known for her enterprising spirit and professionalism. She is a born entrepreneur who knows how to see her business grow and flourish.

loans.use: To diversify her assorted merchandise

loans.name: Volodimir

texts.en:
Volodimir is married and has two children. He is a energetic small-business entrepreneur from Beregovo, Western Ukraine. Volodimir owns real estate and rents his property to legal entities and individuals. The facility he offers for rent is located in a good area of his home town which unfailingly attracts customers who are willing to pay a high rental fee. Volodimir has been in this business for 5 years. Currently, he earns 6,000 Grivnyas of net profit each month. 

Volodimir is seeking a loan of 9, 000 Grivnyas to remodel the facility he owns and leases. He is hoping to expand his floor space as a result and thus increase his income. Volodimir has proved to be a responsible and reliable client with a solid credit history. The current loan will benefit his business and promote its further growth and expansion.  

Note: In the photo, Volodimir is in a hospital uniform.

loans.use: To remodel his rental unit

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is divorced. She has two grown children who live independently. Ludmila started her small business over 11 years ago. Currently, she sells women's outerwear in one of the marketplaces of her home town of Berdyansk. Ludmila has 30,000 Grivnyas of turnover capital. 

Ludmila is requesting a 20,000 Grivnya loan to reconstruct her little store and stock it with additional assorted merchandise for this summer season. She is hoping to keep her business sustainable despite usual slack summer season when market sales go down, and the devastating economic crisis that affected all spheres of Ukrainian small business.

loans.use: To reconstruct her vending facility and re-stock it with merchandise

loans.name: Mujeres Activas Group

texts.es:
El Comité Mujeres Activas es un excelente  comité conformado en fecha 22 de Marzo del 2010, integrado por 15  mujeres de la ciudad de Ita. Este grupo se formó  gracias a que la Sra. Fermina Morán se acercó a la asesora y conformaron el grupo, y ahora ya se encuentran trabajando muy contentas en el 2° ciclo del Programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
Las integrantes de este grupo destinan su crédito a diferentes actividades  tales como: compra de frutas y verduras, compra ingredientes para la preparación de alimentos, compra de mercerías, compra de mercaderías para la despensa (azúcar, arroz, yerba, panificados, lácteos, carnes, etc.), compra de ropa para la venta. .
Es un grupo muy activo, todas las integrantes demuestran compañerismo y solidaridad, asisten a las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos para el bien común del grupo. .
Dentro del grupo se encuentra la señora Fermina quien se dedica a la venta de ropas, ella comenzó con esta actividad después de integrar comité de mujeres. .
Ella ofrece sus mercaderías a su casa, y también sale a ofrecer en casas de conocidos  y amigos. .
Le va bien hasta ahora ya que le genera un ingreso, e invierte en su casa, y actualmente quiere comprar más prendas de vestir para contar con mas variedades como remeras, vestidos, suéter, pantalones, jeans, para solicita el crédito.
texts.en:
The committee Mujeres Activas is an excellent committee formed on March 22, 2010, and is made up of 15 women from the city of Capiatá. This group was formed thanks to Fermina who went up to the assessor and formed the group. Now she finds herself working very contently in the second cycle of the Program of the Committee of Enterprising Women. The members of this group use their loans for different activities like: buying fruits and vegetables, buying ingredients for the preperation of food, buying for a notions store, buying merchandise for a market ( sugar, rice, maté, breads, dairy, meats, etc.), and buying clothes for resale. It is a very active group, all of the members show comradeship and solidarity, they attend the weekly meetings and do activities to collect funds for the common good of the group. In the group is Fermina who works selling clothes. She began this job after forming the committee of women. She offers her merchandise from her house and also leaves to offer in houses of her friends. It has gone well up to now as it creates an income, which she invests in her house for various things, and now she wants to buy more items of clothing to have more varieties like T-shirts, dresses, sweaters, pants, and jeans. This is why she needs the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Gerrit Larsen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy T-shirts, dresses, sweaters, pants, and jeans.

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is married with two children. She sells clothing at the central market in Ivano-Frankivsk town. Ludmila started this business eight years ago. She used to work as a salesperson for her sister and then decided to start her own business. She enjoys selling clothing and has plans to develop her business further. Her goal is to start one more location at the same market. This business is the main source of income for Larisa's family.

Ludmila would like to borrow 6,500 UAH to increase her assortment. She hopes to receive additional income and finish remodeling in her house.

loans.use: To increase the assortment

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en: Maribel E. is a 28 year old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Barangay Lomboy, Tanjay City, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Maribel is now borrowing PHP 21,000 so that she can buy more stock for her general store. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Maribel aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For Additional Working Capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther W. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, beans and pulses (groundnuts, peas, cowpeas) measured by the cup to customers at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize flour and beans to sell.  

Esther is 45 years old and married to a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children and provide necessary scholastic materials, like shoes, school bags, etc.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of maize flour and beans to sell

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en: Ethel A., 40 years old, is a married woman who supports her family by engaging in a food vending business. She lives in Manapla, Negros Occidental with her husband and their 3 children. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000. Ethel is now borrowing PHP 9,500 so that she can use it as additional working capital. This will be her 3rd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Ethel aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Che

texts.en:
A. S. is married and blessed with two children. She resides in Ntamulung where she operates her business.

Due to problems involving her husband and a consequent lack of funds to care for her children, a friend advised her to join GHAPE, which she did in 2008. Her first loan of 40,000 FCFA was paid to her and a second loan of 150,000 FCFA in 2009. These loans have significantly improved her wellbeing and the business which she is running. A. want to invest her profits and this loan in medicines to sell.
The loan will help her community because drugs will be accessible to the sick and the health of the community will improve. Also, money circulation will increase in her community. She believes the business will succeed because she does not have many competitors and her capital has increased.

A. will use the profit to increase her capital, pay fees for the children, and buy food for her home.
She prefers GHAPE loans because they are simple to pay off, and she appreciates the management techniques that GHAPE teaches their clients.

About GHAPE 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buy medicines to sell.

loans.name: Donna Mae

texts.en: Donna Mae P. is a married woman who lives in Proper, Barangay Gen. Malvar, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a rice-retailing business. Her husband, Rogelio P., who is 44 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are from 10 to 16 years old. Donna Mae joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, thus uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th loan, Donna Mae is borrowing PHP 11,000 which she intends to use to buy rice and additional items for her general store so that she can continue to save for future home repairs and for the education of her children. Donna Mae is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy more rice and additional items for her general store

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter would like a loan to buy flour, sugar and salt for his retail shop which he has run for one year. He started by making daily sales of 10,000 shillings and now he makes at least 25,000 shillings.

Peter is a 24-year-old single man who lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He owns the house he lives in. His dream is to become financially stable and turn his retail shop into a wholesale shop in future.

loans.use: To buy more flour, sugar and salt for his shop

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha P. is currently in the business of selling used clothes and bedsheets at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more used clothes to sell.  Asha is 46 years old and is married with a husband who is a police officer. She has five children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a sewing machine and build a shop where clothes would be sewed. 

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en: Rosie M. is a 36-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: pig-fattening, rice-retailing and farming. She lives in Purok 1, M. H. Del Pilar, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. Rosie has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her pig-fattening, rice-retailing and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP 15,000. Rosie is now borrowing PHP 29,500 so that she can buy more piglets and rice for her businesses. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 27,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Rosie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and rice for her businesses

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily D. is a married woman who lives in Purok Kagaykay, Barangay Miranda, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a food-vending business. Her husband, Jesus D., who is 41 years old, works as a salesman to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have three children who are from 3 to 13 years old. Emily joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past eleven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th loan, Emily is borrowing PHP 19,500 which she intends to use to buy additional items and ingredients for her businesses so that she can continue to save for her family’s future and for the education of her children. Emily is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional items and ingredients for her businesses

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en: Marlene T. is a 45-year-old married woman who lives in Sto. Canonoy, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by engaging in fishing and fish vending. Marlene’s 50-year-old husband, Jose Jolito, is a fisherman and they have six children who are between 18 and 27 years old. Some of their children are already working in order to help them in defraying family and other expenses. Marlene joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a fishing and fish-vending business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 12,000 from her business activities. Marlene is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 18,000 was used to fund operations of her fishing and fish-vending business and it had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now, Marlene is borrowing Php 8,000 for her 16th loan which she intends to use for her fishing and fish-vending business. She is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her fishing and fish-vending business

loans.name: Marther

texts.en:
Marther D. is currently in the business of selling both dried and fresh fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish to sell.  Marther is 46 years old and is married with a husband who is a soldier. She has five children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by purchaing bags of pulses and beans, and also, build a shop from which these food items can be sold.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Jorema

texts.en:
Jorema M. is a 45-year-old married woman who lives in Sto. Canonoy, Miranda, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by  fishing and fish-vending business.

Jorema’s 47-year-old husband, Renaldo, is a fisherman and they have seven children who are between 4 to 27 years old. Two of their children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. The rest of their children already work to help support the family.

Jorema joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her fishing and fish-vending business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000 from her business activities.

Jorema is a member of good standing. She used her previous loan of Php 18,000 to add to her working capital so that she could sustainably expand the operations of her fishing and fish-vending business and it had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Based on previous experience, she anticipates her business turnover to slowdown a bit because of the rainy season, this is the reason why she is borrowing a smaller loan of  Php 10,000 for her 18th loan, the amount she has projected to be enough to continue sustaining her business operations.

Jorema is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.


About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her fishing and fish-vending business

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa N. is a 34 year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: a general store and a piggery business. She lives in Purok Block 4 Bless Project, Barangay Guimbalaon, Silay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and piggery businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP 6,000. Marissa is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can buy more stock for her general store. This will be her 5th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Marissa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima L., 50 years old, is a married woman who supports her family by engaging in the buying and selling of gallons of coconut wine. She lives in Barangay Natimaw-an, Carmen, Cebu City with her husband Romaldo and their 5 children who are between 5 and 28 years old. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business of buying and selling of gallons of coconut wine, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,800. Fatima is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can use it as additional working capital. This will be her 5th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Fatima aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Generosa

texts.en: Generosa A., 47 years old, is a married woman who supports her family by engaging in a business buying and selling used clothing. She lives in Barangay Calape Daan Bantayan, Cebu City with her 51 year old husband, Emelito, who is an electrician, and their 6 children who are between 13 and 29 years old. Two of their children have their own families while the other four are currently going to school. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business of buying and selling used clothing, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000. Generosa is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can use it as additional working capital for her business. This will be her 5th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Generosa aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella O. is currently in the business of selling and brewing a local alcoholic beverage at home, and is requesting a loan to stock brewing materials, like tins and yeast, so she can brew more to sell.  Stella is 29 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar and stock crates of beer to sell.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase brewing materials

loans.name: Isabelita

texts.en:
Isabelita G. is a 63-year-old married woman who supports her family by her pig-fattening business. She lives in Barangay Binaliw, Danao City, Cebu City with her 62-year-old husband, Wilfredo, who is a foreman, and their five children who are between 26 and 43 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her pig-fattening business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $330 a month.

Isabelita is now borrowing 10,000 PHP to use as additional working capital for her business. This will be her 8th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 20,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Isabelita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Sonia Emely

texts.es:
Sonia tiene 25 años de años de edad, reside en Cacaópera del departamento de  Morazán   está acompañada tiene tres hijos entre las edades  de 1 a 8 años, vive con su compañero de vida, se dedica a la venta de productos de primera necesidad (tienda).
