loans.name: Virgette

texts.en:
Virgette A. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 27 years old. Virgette is single and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Virgette owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling of used-clothing (ukay-ukay), and also buying and selling ready-to-wear products in the local community. Virgette has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virgette joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgette has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Virgette is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Virgette from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Isidora

texts.en:
Isidora E. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 64 years old. Isidora is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Isidora owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products, and also making and selling coco-charcoal (from coconut shells) in the local community. Isidora has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Isidora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Isidora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Isidora is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Isidora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

To make a living, Jacqueline owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Jacqueline is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jacqueline from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Reynante

texts.en:
Reynante S. is from the village of Omayco, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 31 years old. Reynante is separated from wife and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Reynante owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. Reynante has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Reynante joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynante has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide services. Reynante is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Reynante from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Sana's Group

texts.en: Sana is a citizen of a city called Lahore, in Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. She is a very simple and kind lady. She likes to spend time at her home and to serve her family. Her husband's name is A. M., who is a rickshaw driver by profession. A few months ago he purchased a rickshaw on installments and now wants to pay off its remaining installments at once. This will help him to save more money, because the installment amount is large and he has to put his savings towards completing the installments. Therefore, Sana has applied for a loan from Asasah for this purpose. She is hopeful that by owning the rickshaw her husband will be more mentally satisfied and able to work more efficiently.

loans.use: To pay off the remaining installments of rickshaw.

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla J. is from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 34 years old. Perla is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Perla owns and operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling different varieties of ocean-caught fish in the local community. Perla has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Perla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Perla is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Perla from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Brigette

texts.en:
Brigette P. is a 33-year-old married woman who supports her family through her general store business. She lives in Brgy Lakawon, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their two children.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her family's living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP).

Brigette is now borrowing 20,000 PHP to have additional working capital for her general store.  Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Brigette aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Twenty-four year old Maricel Enriquez wishes for a life that is comfortable for her family, and takes care of them from the profits she earns from her “sari-sari” store and rice retail business, in addition to the income of her 26 year old husband, who is a hired laborer. Presently, Maricel and her husband Jimmy have one child. Despite her early marriage and motherhood, Maricel is very protective of her son. She doesn’t want her child to suffer different forms of oppression due to poverty, just like her and her husband, because they knew how it feels to live a life with so many boundaries. Maricel is still in the process of getting to know herself and her potential in a wider perspective.
 
Her membership in ASHI is one of the best things that happened to her life. Through ASHI she has able to improve the social aspect of her personality because in every ASHI activity she meets a lot of women from other villages and municipalities. The loans she received since 2009 have enabled her to enhance her capability to become productive. Small proceeds from her business somehow enable her to support the needs of her family.

Through the loan Maricel is requesting presently from KIVA through ASHI, she hopes to sustain the operation of her “sari-sari” store, which is just a small store. The inventory is composed of a few varieties of grocery items, foodstuffs, and beverages. Someday, she hopes that this will turn into a mini-grocery store which can sell large volumes of grocery items, foodstuffs, and beverages. Unlike “sari-sari” store, which can only accommodate resales, a mini-grocery store has the capacity to sell wholesale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items, varieties of foodstuffs, rice and beverages to resell.

loans.name: Inabat's Group

texts.en: Inabat S. is the leader of this group. She is 44 and married. Her husband works as an electrician and they have three sons and a daughter. The older son and the daughter are farmers and the other children are students. Inabat owns a piece of land on which she cultivates fruits and vegetables. She also breeds cattle and sells milk. She has been doing this for eighteen years and in this way she makes 5,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fertilizer for her farming activity. In the future Inabat plans to repair her house and save some money to contribute to her son’s wedding. Abdurahman S., 45, is married. He works as a security guard and his wife works as a cleaner at a school. They have two daughters and a son: the older daughter studies at school but the others are not yet old enough. In order to make money Abdurahman also breeds cattle which he has been doing for twenty years. By selling some animals after fattening, he makes him 3,000 soms per month. Now he has applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase a calf to raise. Inoyathon A., 36, is divorced. Five years ago, with an initial investment of 7,000 soms, she started to breed cattle. By selling some cattle after fattening, she makes 3,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan she wants to purchase a cow for breeding. In the future she plans to repair her house. Aitbu S., 45, is divorced. She has raised two sons: the first son went to Russia to work to earn some money and the second works in the factory in Bishkek. Aitbu works as a nurse and receives 2,500 soms per month. She also has a piece of land where she cultivates corn. By selling the harvest, she makes 5,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan she plans to purchase fertilizer for her farming activity. In the future she wants to purchase a plot of land and build a new house for her son. Mahsadhan S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 46, a widow, and she has a son and a daughter. The son went to Russia to work to earn some money and the daughter helps at home with housework. Mahsadhan works as a nurse in the hospital and receives 2,500 soms per month. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 2,000 soms, she began to breed cattle. By selling some cattle after fattening, she makes 3,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan she wants to purchase a cow. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her farming business

loans.name: Rozi's Group

texts.en:
Rozi is a citizen of a city called Lahore in Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. A very talented lady, Rozi owns and operates a clothes sales business. Her clientele base is her neighbors and relatives. She used to just sell to her neighbors, but later on her relatives came to see her collection and started giving her orders.
 
Her husband's name is M. M., who is a driver by profession. He drives a rented rickshaw and earns an income. His business has struggled because he has to share his earnings with the owner of the rickshaw. Therefore, Rozi has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount her husband will purchase his own rickshaw, earn more income, and work with more efficiency.

loans.use: To purchase a rickshaw.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Mrs. S., 36 years old, is a humble villager living in the capital, Phnom Penh, in the middle of Cambodia. She is married and blessed with two young school-aged kids, while her husband is a motorbike taxi driver.

S. works sewing clothes in the garment factory and gets a specific salary to meet the needs of her family. S. has been planning to get a sewing machine that she will use to sew the neighbor's clothes, but she doesn’t have money yet to buy one. This is why S. decided to pursue a loan of $700 through Kiva’s field partner, HKL, to meet the requirements above. Unfortunately, the motor-taxi is often broken down, so S. will use some part of the loan to repair it.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and to repair the broken motor-taxi.

loans.name: Thu

texts.en: Thu T. N. is 41 years old. She lives in Xom Ngoai village. She not only grows rice, but also sells building materials. She has two children who are going to school. She has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2004 and repaid punctually. The last cycle she borrowed 6,322,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,502,000 VND to invest in her shop.

loans.use: To invest in her shop.

loans.name: Khan

texts.en:
Khan S. is a widow who is 46 years old and resides in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, and her birth place. Khan S. currently sells vegetables that she grows on her own farmland in the village. Normally, Khan S. needs to wait three months before harvesting and selling her mature crop.

She has five children:  four are married and live independently and the other one is single and works with her on the farm. Khan S. has another financial earner in her husband, who works in the construction sector. This is the second loan she has requested from Kiva. Khan S. will be using this loan to purchase a motorbike to make her family's transportation easier, and she can use it to pick up vegetables as well.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en:
Mrs. Suon H. was born in 1976 and is a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

Suon H. has been operating a farming business in her village for more tH. fifteen years. She normally raises rice, vegetables and pigs but she is also flexible, doing what is appropriate for the conditions of different seasons. Another part of the family’s income comes from her husband, who sells chickens to earn a living.

Suon H. is married with four single children, all of whom are students and work with her business when they are not studying.

Suon H. will use the Kiva loan to buy piglets for her stall. She also intends to use a part of the loan to order rice to stock for later sale to raise income.

loans.use: To buy piglets for her stall and rice to store and sell

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials for his car repair service

loans.name: Meoun

texts.en: Mrs. Meoun S. is 38 years old, married to Sovann, 55. They have three school-aged children who are dependent on them. The couple sells recycled goods. They buy used goods door-to-door around their community and sell them to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods they deal in are mostly leftover electrical wires, plastics, and cans. The family's living conditions are not comfortable because their house is too old and broken. Meoun S. is asking for a loan to mend their old house.

loans.use: To mend their old house.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia B. is from the village of  Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 47 years old and married with two adult children. To make a living, Amalia runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products. Amalia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Amalia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amalia is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Amalia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes M. is from the village of San Isidro, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Lourdes owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lourdes joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes is requesting a first loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Bilquis Begum's Group

texts.en:
Bilquis begum lives in the city of Lahore in Pakistan.  Lahore is famous for its historical places and Punjabi food. 

She is the mother of three children who all do different work to earn their living. Her elder son is involved in a clothing selling business. Builquis husband makes shoe boxes and she also helps him in his business. They collect orders from the shoe factories and earn a good profit by returning them on time.  
Bilquis has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her elder son in his clothes selling business. With the loan amount he will buy clothes in bulk which will reduce his costs of traveling and purchasing. 

Bilquis is hopeful that this investment will prove to be a profitable one for her son.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: El

texts.en: Mrs. El M., age 40, is a married woman and a good house wife. She takes care of two young children who go to school every day. The family is contributed to by El M.’s husband, who works as a civil servant officer in the ministry of interior. Also, he operates his own small business which buys and sells wooden furniture. Recently, there are many customers who order his furniture but he can’t satisfy the needs of his customers due to a lack of funds. So, El M. has decided to request a loan of $1,000 for her husband to purchase wooden furniture to resell to raise a profit.

loans.use: To purchase wooden furniture to resell.

loans.name: Safia Begum's Group

texts.en:
Safia begum is the resident of the city of Lahore in Pakistan where her husband sells vegetables from his shop to earn a living for his family. She has four children and none of them could get an education due to financial constraints. 

Safia begum does cloth stitching work to financially support her husband. She takes orders from different areas and fulfills them to earn money. 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband in his vegetable selling business. With the loan, he will buy seasonal vegetables for his shop and increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal vegetables.

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima G. is from the village of San Isidro, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 59 years-old and married with seven adult children. To make a living, Maxima owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Maxima has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2005, Maxima joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maxima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maxima is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Maxima from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Ninfa

texts.en:
Ma. Ninfa O. has been a member of ASHI since 2009. Hoping to change the kind of lifestyle her family is having right now, and without any further training to manage a business, she had the courage to request a loan to invest in putting up a sari-sari (variety) store. This way she would be able to have her own income and augment her husband’s small income as a hired laborer.

Paying for all the expenses her family requires every day from the income generated by her sari-sari store and from her husband’s income, most often Ma. Ninfa feels insecure about sustaining her business and the education of her children. However, with the opportunity to request a loan from ASHI, her hopes are rekindled.

Now, Ma. Ninfa is requesting a much larger loan to increase the inventory of her sari-sari store. A sari-sari store is just a small store, either a cottage separated from the owner’s house or attached to the owner’s house. The inventories are composed of a few grocery items, foodstuffs, and beverages.

Ma. Ninfa, is looking forward to seeing her sari-sari store turning into a mini-grocery store that sells a large volume of grocery items, foodstuffs, and beverages. Unlike a sari-sari store, which can only sell retail, a mini-grocery store has the capacity to sell wholesale. Along with this she hopes that it will become sustainable and profitable, making her family financially stable. This will enable her to support the education of her two children until they graduate from college.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items, foodstuffs and beverages for her store

loans.name: Firdous' Group

texts.en:
Firdous is a very hardworking lady. She is a seamstress and works very hard to financially support her family members: herself, her husband and her seven children. Her husband is a laundryman who also works hard to manage the finances of the family. They both utilize their money to pay the utilities and also to save money for a rainy day.

Seeing their dedication towards their work, their elder daughter has started paying attention to her mother’s work. Therefore, Firdous has applied for a loan from Asasah because she wants to buy a sewing machine for her daughter who is able to work on her own. In this way, Firdos can earn more income and able to fulfill more orders in less time.

loans.use: To purchase another sewing machine for her sewing business that her daughter will use

loans.name: Batdelger

texts.en:
Batdelger S., 49, is married, and is the father of two daughters. He and his family live together in a house, which they own, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His oldest daughter, Battsetseg, attends a local university and his younger daughter, Bat-Otgon, attends a local secondary school. His wife, Otgonchimeg, is unemployed.

Batdelger has been successfully operating his business, a small car repair business that they started in 1992. At first, the couple rented a small tire repair shop, but after a year of successful business operation, he managed to build the garage and expand his services.

Batdelger and his family have been planning to grow their business in the future. Batdelger is a helpful person with a good personality. He says, “My dream is one day to change my repair place into a large and warm auto repair service.” He is requesting a 1,600,000 tugrug loan to purchase more equipment.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment for his repair shop

loans.name: Evelia

texts.en: Evelia A. is from the village of Camuayan, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old and is married with three adult children. Evelia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Evelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Evelia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Juditha

texts.en: Juditha T. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 54 years old and is married with two adult children. Juditha owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily selling specialty food products in the local community like tablea, a local term for ground chocolate beans, best for hot chocolate drinks. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 1994, Juditha joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Juditha is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn R., 22 years old and married, is from the village of Plaridel, Claveria, Misamis Oriental, where she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Marlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP for the same purpose. Marlyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kosar Parveen

texts.en:
Kosar Parveen lives in Lahore Pakistan with her husband and five children. Her husband has been making pouches (small bags) and doing printing work for 13 years. Kosar assists him in his business by making pouches (small bags) and by staying at home. Her two elder children also help their parents in their business after they return from school.

Kosar wants to help her husband expand his business and so is requesting a loan from Asasah worth 80,000 PKRs to purchase the raw materials needed for pouches and printing.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for printing and for pouch-making (small bags) business

loans.name: Mr. Nath Say Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eighteen people in the village of Mkak in Kandal province have formed a loan group and selected Mr. Nath S., who was born in 1977, as the leader. All the members will use their portion of the loan to improve their businesses in the current year. 

Mr. Nath S. farms a small piece of land he owns to grow crops to sell to support his family; he is also a barber. His wife, Mrs. Sok Khen Sorn, is a seamstress in a garment factory and helps support their family with her small salary. Now Mr. Nath S. has a problem because his field has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mr. Nath S. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. He is a father of two children, one of whom is enrolled in a local public school, while the other is too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is from the village of Gaston, Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She is 60 years old. Erlinda is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erlinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Erlinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Phorn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phorn V., who is 61 years old, is the group leader and she has been selected by the five members who make up this group loan located in Mkak village in Kandal province. Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose so as to improve their living.

Mrs. Phorn V. is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land she uses to grow a crop to sell to support her family. She is also a seamstress in a garment factory.

Now, Mrs. Phorn V. has a problem because her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer.

Mrs. Phorn V. is the mother of two children, one of whom is a construction worker and, besides this, is a motorbike taxi driver, while the other is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Nana

texts.fr:
Madame Nana T. est une femme mariée de 48 ans et mère de 5 enfants qui vit avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier  Hérémakono-Nord de Bougouni (troisième région administrative du Mali)
Madame Nana T. n’a pas  eu la chance de fréquenter l’école moderne. Très vite elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des tissus et draps de lit.  Elle a appris cette activité auprès de sa mère.
Avec 3 années d’expérience, elle maîtrise son activité et est très sollicitée.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, elle décide de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso.
Après 1 prêt  solidaire, elle décida de venir  au prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt ci, pour acheter des tissus et draps de lits.  Elle s’approvisionne au Burkina Faso. Sa clientèle est composée de population locale.
Avec ce prêt, elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 37 000 FCFA qui lui permettra d’améliorer son entreprise et à payer les intérêts.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nana T. is a married woman who is 48 years old and mother to five children. She lives with her husband and children in the Hérémakono-Nord district of Bougouni (Mali's third administrative region). Mrs.T. was not lucky enough to go to modern school. She started her income-generating activities at an early age, notably the purchase and sale of fabrics and bed sheets. She learned this business from her mother. With three years of experience she now masters her business and is in great demand. In her search for complementary financial resources she decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso. Following one group loan, she decided to go for an individual loan. She is planning to use this loan to buy fabrics and bed sheets. She gets her supplies in Burkina Faso. Her customer base is made up of local people. With this loan, she is hoping to make a monthly profit of 37,000FCFA which will allow her to improve her business and to pay the interest.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabrics and bed sheets

loans.name: Ramata

texts.fr:
Madame Ramata Koné est une femme mariée de 38 ans et mère de 6 enfants. Elle vit avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier Hérémakono-Nord de Bougouni (région de Sikasso)
Madame Ramata Koné mène des activités génératrices de revenus dès  son jeune âge. Elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Elle a appris son activité d’achat et vente des pagnes auprès de sa sœur. Avec une expérience de plus de 6 ans elle maîtrise son activité.
Afin d’obtenir un fonds de roulement consistant, elle décide de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso  et  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  des pagnes.
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). La vente de ses articles se fait au marché de Bougouni et dans les différents quartiers  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle espère réaliser ainsi un bénéfice mensuel de 29 000 FCFA
Avec se bénéfice elle compte payer les intérêts du prêt et  agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mme Ramata Koné is 36. She is married with six children, and lives with them and her husband in the Hérémakono-Nord neighborhood of Bougouni (Sikasso region). She never went to school, and has earned her own living since she was young. She learned from her sister how to buy and sell traditional cloth, and after six years doing it she is an expert. To build working capital, she decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, and plans on using her loan to buy cloth in Bamako (Mali's capital). She will sell it in the market in Bougouni and other places to her largely female customers. She hopes to realize a monthly profit of 29,000 FCFA (about $56 US) to pay loan interest and grow her business.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy traditional cloth

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Among Gloria O.’s dreams is to see her three children graduate from college. This is her most precious dream and something she works hard for. For people who are poor like her, few are able to achieve this goal. Gloria O. married five years ago. Now, she is just 21 years old and her husband is 33 years old. Because her parents were poor, she was not able to pursue her education. Instead, she married, thinking that her life would be better that way. Because of the love and support of her husband, her life as a wife and a mother is not bad, yet it is not what her parents wanted her to have.

For Gloria, it is never too late to improve her life and to lead her children toward a life that is better and more comfortable. Through the loan she is requesting right now through ASHI, she will grow her business of buying and selling fruit. While her children are still young (age ranges are from one to five), she wants to increase her capital investment until her business becomes profitable. With this, she will be able to support the financial needs of her children to provide a better and higher level of education for them. In the future, Gloria will be confident to say that poverty is not an obstacle to reaching success.

loans.use: To purchase fruit to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Roeun Ya Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Roeun Y., who was born in 1978, is the village bank president selected by the eighteen members located in Khsom village in Kandal province. The members will each use their portion of the loan for a different purpose to improve their living.

Mrs. Roeun Y. is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family and she is a fish-seller who sells some fish that her husband, Mr. Lab Lun, a fisherman, catches.

This couple has a big problem because their fishing supplies are too little to use. So, to solve this large problem, Mrs. Roeun Y. is asking for a loan to buy more fishing supplies.

Mrs. Roeun Y. is the mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school while the others are too small to study or work.

loans.use: To buy more fishing supplies

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith B. is from the village of Waterfall, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old. Judith is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Judith owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling native delicacies for snacks and also selling ready-to-wear products in the local community. Judith has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Judith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Judith has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Judith is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Judith from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sheria Group

texts.fr:
Vumilia N. A. est  entrepreneur, productrice de boisson locale communément appelé  « Rutuku », elle lève sa main sur la photo, avec une petite sourire aux lèvres, excellente cliente de groupe de crédit Sheria (qui signifie lois, règlements),  âgée de 50 ans, veuve, mère de 5 enfants dont 4 filles et 1 garçons, le cadet, qui fait la 6e primaire.   Les 4 filles ont leurs propres foyers. Vumilia  N.  A.  réside dans le village  Kiziba II, périphérie et  bidon ville de la ville de Goma, commune de Nyiragongo. 
Son mari est décédé dans les années 2006 suite à une longue maladie de diabète. De façon sommaire, Rutuku est une boisson  alcoolisée d’environ 47% produite en base de solution ou mélange des moisissures des Farine de manioc, maïs, sorgho, etc. chauffée au feu à plus de 180o C , à travers une vase connectée à un cheminé d’évacuation de technologie locale. Les goutes raffinées d’évaporation issues de ce cheminé sont accueillies dans une cuvette et  refroidies pour donner un gout d’une liqueur forte de Whisky apprécié par les buveurs. 
La veuve  Vumilia N. A.  a commencé son business  avec  son fonds propre avec un capital initial de 20$, un peu  après, elle fut informée de  l’IMF Hekima,  et bénéficia son premier crédit de 50$ pour renforcer son business. Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, la veuve  Vumilia N. A. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant  2 sacs des Maïs, 2 sacs de farines maniocs, une dizaine des  tas de bois de chauffages, etc. 
Vumilia N. A., explique le défi majeur de son activité de production de boissons locales Rutuku est lié aux ventes en  crédit, le manque ou rareté des bois de chauffage surtout comme l’Etat a déjà pris de mesures pénales aux destructeurs de l’environnement (vendeurs de bois de parc national). En plus parfois lorsque le mélange des intrants n’a pas bien être solutionné, on produit une boisson (liqueur whisky) non appréciée par les consommateurs, ils se réservent de l’acheter.
Vue l’avancement de son âge et les dures conditions de production de cette boisson, la veuve  Vumilia N. A. souhaite changer  son activité  en vendant aussi les habits et  produits divers de commerce général  en provenance de Kampala(Ouganda).  En outre, elle compte construire une maison confortable dans sa parcelle.
La veuve  Vumilia N. A. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir à ses besoins personnels et aux besoins de ses enfants et petits fils. Elle reconnait de l’IMF Hekima sa banque de proximité qui œuvre pour les pauvres et  veuves. 
Le groupe Sheria est composé de 17 membres femmes. Les membres  portent une tenue uniforme d’union et d’unité dans les affaires en  mémoire de la journée internationale de la femme du 8 mars 2010.
texts.en:
A. Vumilia N. is an entrepreneur who produces a local drink known as "Rutuku". On the photo, she is the one raising her hand, with a little smile. An excellent client of the Sheria solidarity group (Sheria means laws, regulations), she is 50, a widow and mother of five children, four girls and a boy. The boy is the youngest and he attends 6th grade. The four girls have their own homes. A. lives in the village of Kiziba II, a shantytown on the outskirts of Goma, a commune of Nyiragongo. Her husband died in 2006 after a lengthy battle against diabetes. Rutuku is basically an alcoholic beverage about 47% proof, brewed from a mixture of fermented cassava flour, maize, sorghum, etc. It is heated to more than 180C in a vessel connected to a locally-designed chimney pipe. The droplets resulting from the evaporation process are collected in a bowl and cooled to achieve the taste of strong Whiskey liquor, which the customers enjoy. A. started her business with her own money, an initial capital of $20. Soon after, she found out about the Hekima MFI and received her first loan of $50 to strengthen her business. With a new loan from the Hekima MFI, A. hopes to increase her sales by buying two bags of maize, two bags of cassava flour, about ten stacks of firewood, etc. A. has explained that the main challenges of producing the local beverage Rutuku are the sales on credit and the lack or scarcity of firewood, especially now that the state has already taken steps to impose criminal sanctions on anyone who harms the environment (people selling wood from the national park). Moreover, when the mixture of ingredients doesn’t dissolve properly, the customers don’t like the beverage and are reluctant to buy it. Given her advancing age and the harsh conditions surrounding the production of the beverage, A. wants to make changes to her activities by adding a new business selling clothes and various items from Kampala, Uganda. She also plans to build a comfortable house on her plot. A. is grateful for the loans that the Hekima MFI grants her without any material guarantees because these funds allow her to support herself and provide for the needs of her children and grandsons. She recognizes the Hekima MFI as the local bank dedicated to helping the poor and the widows. The Sheria group consists of 17 female members. All members are wearing a uniform in solidarity and unity to commemorate the International Women’s Day of March 8, 2010.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase two bags of maize, two bags of cassava flour, about ten stacks of firewood, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Presentacion

texts.en:
Presentacion V. is from the village of Waterfall, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old. Presentacion is married and has nine adult children. To make a living, Presentacion owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Presentacion has been engaged in her business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Presentacion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Presentacion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Presentacion is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Presentacion from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Mrs. Sopheak Vann Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of twenty-one people who live in Khsom village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sopheak V., who was born in 1987, is the village bank president selected by the other members. The members will each use their loan for a different purpose to improve their living.

Mrs. Sopheak V. is a seamstress in a garment factory where she earns a low salary to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Bros Yen, is a fisherman.

Now, Mrs. Sopheak V. has a problem because her husband does not have a fishing boat to use. So, to improve his fishing, she is seeking a loan to buy a fishing boat for him to use.

Mrs. Sopheak V. is the mother of two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school while the other is too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat for her husband to use

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 35-year-old married woman from Lebanon who has two school-aged children. She worked for eight years as a cook in a restaurant. She has been running her own restaurant since 2008. Her restaurant specializes in serving the most delicious fajitas in town. People from the neighboring villages also visit her restaurant to taste the delicious food she offers. 

In order to help with her family’s expenses, she is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase materials needed for the restaurant. She hopes that the loan will positively impact her business and, therefore, increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase restaurant materials

loans.name: Mr. Houy Um Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people who live in Khsom village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. Mr. Houy U., who was born in 1954, is the village bank president, selected by the other members. Each member will use their loan for a different purpose.

Mr. Houy U. is a fisherman who is able to earn some money to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Lou Ork, is a housewife who makes some delicious food for her family.

Now Mr. Houy U. has a problem because his fishing supplies are too little to use. So, to improve his fishing, he is applying for a loan to buy more fishing supplies to use. He will use the rest of his loan to buy soil and zinc to build a place to conduct motorbike repairs to start a new business.

Mr. Houy U. is the father of six children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more fishing supplies plus equipment to start a new business

loans.name: Chheang

texts.en: Mrs. S. has spent her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. She is now married and has three unmarried children. One of her children is a teacher at the secondary school. Her husband appears in the photo and he works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual activity with which she has had great success. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. The coming rainfall is good for growing.  However, S. doesn’t have sufficient capital to use on her farm. Therefore, S. is looking for a loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and rice seeds for planting.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and rice seeds for planting.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old unmarried man from Lebanon. He is living with his family. This young entrepreneur is an experienced men's hairdresser.  He has almost five years of experience in this occupation. He also works with his brother to help their father who works as a farmer with a small income for the household. He opened his barbershop in 2007. 

With this loan request from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. he is planning to expand his business by purchasing hairdressing supplies such as wax, gel, etc. to attract more and serve a bigger range of clients.

loans.use: To purchase hairdressing supplies.

loans.name: Chay

texts.en: Chay C. is a 46-year-old woman, married to Noun Heang, age 51. They have four married children who have already started new homes. Chay C. currently plants crops, which she will harvest and collect when they are mature. In order to help alleviate the hard physical labor of farming, Chay C. is taking out her first loan to purchase a cow that she will use to plow the farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a cow.

loans.name: Nadjati

texts.fr:
Cette femme de 40 ans est une dame très dynamique, elle exerce depuis 10 ans déjà le commerce de céréales, elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville d’anié ainsi ses marges bénéficiaires sont  plus élevées. Sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. Le céréale est très utilisé dans la cuisine togolaise. Elle voudrait gonfler son stock de marchandise, elle sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour l’achat des  sacs de maïs, des sacs d’haricots, des sacs de sorghos et des sacs de mil.
 Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
This 40-year-old lady is very energetic. For ten years she has been selling cereals, which she buys upcountry in her home town so she can make more profit. Her customers are from all backgrounds. Cereals are a big part of the Togolese diet. To build her stock, she's asking WAGES for her first loan so she can buy corn, beans, sorghum and millet. She is married, with one child.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cereals

loans.name: Dy

texts.en: Mrs. Dy S. is 27 year of age and single. She lives with her mother who is shown in the photo. Dy S. works in a company located in the middle of Phnom Penh City and earns a salary of $150 of a month. She has two financial helpers in her younger sisters who are employed in a small firm. Dy S. is taking out this loan as capital to start a vehicle-cleaning service for additional income and will also use part of the loan to repair her old house.

loans.use: To begin a vehicle-cleaning service.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new fabrics to broaden her range of goods.

loans.name: Saodatjon

texts.en:
J. Saodatjon is 52 years old and a widow with three children. She makes dried apricots and processes the stones to sell at the local market. This is her main income and it provides a steady cash flow. She always makes very productive use of her capital, adding inventory to her supply in a way that allows her to meet her customers' needs. She is requesting a loan which will be used to restock her inventory of dried apricots. Saodatjon will be happy if she can get this loan. It would help raise her family income, which is really necessary for her. She deeply appreciates your support and would like to thank all of you.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to restock her inventory of dried apricots

loans.name: Hidoyat

texts.en:
K. Hidoyat is married and has four children. The knowledge acquired from her parents and grandparents has contributed to Hidoyat's work raising cattle in a special space in her home. Hidoyat's work in animal sales generates a good income for her family. Currently she has two cows in her house. She would like to increase little by little the variety of her animals and is seeking a loan of 6000 Somoni. Hidoyat’s dream is to see her children through their education.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing calves and fodder.

loans.name: Abdugaffar

texts.ru: Курбонов Абдугаффар проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 48 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Сын зарабатывает строительными работами. Сам Абдугаффар имеет высшее образование, экономист. По профессии проработал 10 лет. Сейчас он занимается животноводством. Откармливает и продает скот. Этим видом бизнеса занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота. Он хочет увеличить количество скот.
texts.en:
Abdugaffar K. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 48 years old, married, and has four children. His son does construction work. Abdugaffar has a college degree in economics. He worked in his profession for ten years. Now, he works in animal husbandry. He fattens and sells cattle. He has been doing this for six years. He is taking out a loan to buy cattle. He wants to increase his herd.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old married man and the father of three school-age children. He owns a small shop where he makes delicious fresh juices. He is an experienced vendor — and has been selling juice for almost nine years. He is his family's main provider. The availability of fresh juice all year round is one of Lebanon’s many great features. Depending on the season, it is possible to find juices such as mango, pomegranate, lemon, and blood orange. Especially during the summer, his sales and his income increase which is why he is requesting a loan of  $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to improve his shop and increase his inventory.

loans.use: improve his shop and increase inventory

loans.name: Aminatou

texts.fr: aminatou O. G. est une femme mariée qui vit avec son époux et ses 3 enfants dans le quartier d’agoè logopé. Pour contribuer financièrement aux charges de sa famille elle s’et lancée en 2003 dans le commerce e de produits d’alimentation générale, elle a ouvert à cet effet sa propre boutique qu’elle a appelé « ETS FATIMA ET FILS ». Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Etant en rupture de stock elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour s’approvisionner avec des sacs de riz, des sacs d’huile et divers produits cosmétiques.
texts.en:
aminatou O. G. is a married woman who lives with her husband and three children in the Agoè Logopé district. In order to contribute financially to the household expenses she began trading in general grocery products in 2003.She opened her own shop for this purpose and called it "Ets Fatima et Fils" ("Fatima and Son"). She gets her supplies at Lomé's large market. Since she has run out of stock she is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to get supplies of bags of rice, bags of oil and various cosmetic products.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general grocery products

loans.name: Kafui

texts.fr: Kafui est une résidente du quartier d’agoè zongo, elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois, elle a près de 4 ans d’expérience dans ce commerce. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville de bassar. Actuellement une partie de son stock est épuisée, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 40 sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandise.
texts.en:
Kafui is a resident of the Agoè Zongo district and is married with two children. She has an income-generating activity selling charcoal, and she has nearly four years' experience in this trade. She gets her supplies inland in the town of Bassar. Her stock is currently low and she would like to get fresh supplies. For this reason she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 40 sacks of charcoal and to cover the costs of transporting the merchandise.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal

loans.name: Nouriatou

texts.fr: Nouriatou est une femme mariée et  mère de 2 enfants, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons et de bois de chauffage. Son stock actuel de marchandises est en baisse, elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 30 sacs de charbons de bois et de  10 tas de bois de chauffage. Elle exerce son commerce à la devanture de sa maison.
texts.en:
Nouriatou, a married woman and a mother of two, is active in the coal and firewood trade as an income-generating activity. Since her current merchandise inventory is diminishing, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase 30 bags of charcoal and 10 piles of firewood. She carries her trade in the front part of her house.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase coal and firewood

loans.name: Midokpe

texts.fr:
Midokpe a découvert  en 1996 le commerce des articles et fournitures scolaires,  ce commerce est très florissant à des périodes comme la rentrée scolaire et la période des examens. Actuellement  la rentrée scolaire approche à Lomé, elle voudrait déjà s’approvisionner et  sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat  des cahiers, livres, ensemble géométrique, des stylos, des règles, des sacs d’écoliers et des tissus kaki.
Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
Midokpe discovered the trade of school supplies and goods in 1996. This business thrives at times such as Back to School or examination season. Back to School time is now approaching in Lomé, and she would like to stock up beforehand. She is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase notebooks, books, geometry kits, pens, rulers, school bags and khaki fabrics. She is married and a mother of one.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase school supplies and goods

loans.name: Ségni Gbessounde

texts.fr:
C. est âgée de 46 ans, elle a ouvert depuis 2005 un salon de coiffure, pour accroître ses recettes  elle  a associé à son activité la vente de produits de beauté. La demande de sa clientèle en produits de beauté est de plus en plus élevée raison pour laquelle elle voudrait gonfler son stock, elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de mèches, tissages, crèmes, défrisants et autres.
Elle est mariée avec un enfant.
texts.en:
Mrs. C. is 46 years old. She opened a hair salon in 2005 and combined cosmetic sales to her activity to increase revenues. Her customers' demand for cosmetics is getting higher and higher; for this reason, she would like to increase her inventory, for which she is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase hair extensions, hair weaves, creams, straighteners and more. She is married and has one child.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is a 43-year-old single lady who operates her shop, “Lily Cosmetics”, to earn her daily bread. Lilian, who is a single mother of two, works hard to educate her children.

Lilian joined Millenium group under Faulu Kenya so as to save her money and to more easily access loans. She previously took out a loan of 15,453 KES to boost her business and has successfully repaid it.

Lilian wants to service another loan, this time KES 50,000. She wants to buy more cosmetics and beauty products with this money.

loans.use: To add to her stock of cosmetics

loans.name: Philis

texts.en:
Philis is a 41-year-old married lady who spends most of her time on her farm. She does dairy farming together with other members of the Gathiruini B group of Faulu Kenya. The group members share business ideas such as new farming methods and new markets. Above all, the group members guarantee each other’s loans.

Philis has requested a loan of Kes 50,000 to buy a dairy cow for better milk production. She hopes to become a large-scale farmer in the future.

loans.use: To add a dairy cow for better milk production

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 31 years old and married with two children. Since 1998, she has been selling building stones, sand and ballast.

Susan joined Faulu Kenya so that she could easily access loans. So far, she has serviced one loan which she used to purchase a piece of land. She has requested a new loan of 40,000 KES to purchase more building materials such as stones, sand and ballast.

Susan hopes to complete the process of building a house on her piece of land. She describes herself as hardworking and visionary.

loans.use: To purchase more building stones, ballast and sand

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena is a member of the Keen Ventures group of Faulu Kenya. She runs "Zena Salon" to earn a living and her business, which has been running for six years, has really grown. Therefore, she has employed two people.

Zena is a married lady with one child and she works hard to support her family financially. She hopes to get more customers for a better income. Therefore, she has requested a loan of 60,000 KES to renovate her salon which will help to attract more customers.

Zena hopes to start a hairdressing school in the future.

loans.use: To renovate her salon

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: Cette femme âgée de 34 ans  s’est lancée en 2000 dans le commerce de détail de produits génériques. Elle s’approvisionne à accra ainsi elle réalise de plus gros profits sur les ventes, elle exerce son commerce dans une boutique non loin du marché local d’agoé à Lomé. Elle voudrait s’approvisionner  et sollicite donc un crédit de WAGES pour l’achat d 4 perfuseurs, 7 boites de  Nuti C,  5 boîtes de Dolo plus, de l’ Amociline et Analgin inject. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants
texts.en:
This 34 year-old woman began retailing generic products in 2000. She gets her supplies at Accra, so she makes a greater profit on her sales. She runs her business in a shop that is not far from the Agoé local market at Lomé. She would like to stock up and is therefore requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 4 intravenous drip lines, 7 boxes of Nutri C (a powdered drink), 5 boxes of dolo (a local beer) plus Amoxicillin and Analgin injection. She is married and the mother of two children.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of generic products

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a member of the Keen Ventures group of Faulu Kenya. She has been doing outside catering for ten years and, in addition, she grows tea and maize for commercial purposes. She was previously employed but went into business so as to earn more income for her family.

Veronica has requested Kes 40,000 to buy more ingredients for preparing food. Veronica, who is widowed, hopes to grow her business so as to provide a better education for her six children. She describes herself as hardworking and aggressive.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old married woman from Lebanon. A mother of 3 young children she opened a shoe shop in 2005. Her business income is important to support her family, especially her children. Today, she is requesting to borrow US$ 1000 to expand her inventory. 

And she hopes that her diverse selection of shoes will continue to generate good profit and enable her to expand her business even further. She expects her productivity and income to increase in the coming year.

loans.use: expand her inventory

loans.name: Mazalou

texts.fr: G. mazalo est une femme mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de  sorad à Lomé. Son époux est un chauffeur. Depuis 2003 elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de sacs de charbons de bois. Elle s’approvisionne au nord du Togo car la bas le sac de charbon de bois est moins coûteux. Elle fait son commerce à la devanture de sa maison. Son stock est en baisse elle veut le rehausser et elle demande donc son deuxième prêt à WAGES afin de s’acheter  30 sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandise.
texts.en:
Mazalo G. is married and has three children. She lives with her family in the Sorad neighborhood of Lome. Her husband is a driver. Since 2003 she has made her living selling charcoal. She buys it in northern Togo where it is cheaper. She sells by the roadside in front of her house. Since her stock is low, she wants to rebuild it. That is why she is asking for a second loan from WAGES to buy 30 sacks of charcoal and to pay for its transportation.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy charcoal

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 59 years old and single.  She sells clothes in Kariobangi open-air market in Nairobi.  She was previously employed in a hardware shop in Nairobi city centre.  Being a single mother of three, her salary could not support her three children.  Therefore, she chose to do business herself to earn more income.  

Her business which has been running for ten years has grown.  This is because she uses her savings to boost her business.  She has requested 60,000 KES to add to her clothing inventory. She hopes to build a home for her family in ten years' time.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a member of 'Transparency' self-help group under Faulu Kenya.  She operates  Hardwork Retail Shop which has been running for one and a half years.  She was previously employed but went into business so as to earn more income.  Her husband is an accountant by profession and he works hard to support her in the business.  

Christine, a mother of two, hopes to venture into a salon business in the future.  For this reason, she wants to expand her shop for better income so as to invest in the salon business.  She has requested 40,000 KES to add stocks of cereals, vegetables, fruit and spices. She describes herself as assertive and hard-working.

loans.use: To add stock of cereals, vegetables, fruits and spices

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is a 27-year-old married lady with two children who go to school. She operates a grocery store and a retail shop and has employed two people to help her run the business.

Cecilia has been an active member of the Jupiter SHG group of Faulu Kenya. Because she pays her weekly dues well, she has previously been guaranteed three loans by the group members.

Cecilia has requested another loan of 40,000 KES to buy construction materials and to add stock to her shop. She hopes to complete building her house and also provide a quality education to her children.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to complete her house and to add stock to her shop

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 38 years old and married with three children who are in school. He has been farming for the past eleven years and also helps his wife in dress-making to supplement his family’s income.

Michael has been an active member of the Ushindi Thiliu group of Faulu Kenya and he attends their weekly meetings regularly. He previously took out a loan of 40,000 KES and successfully repaid it. This has led his group members to guarantee him another loan of 40,000 KES from Faulu Kenya. He will use this loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers, animal feeds and a sewing machine.

Michael hopes to buy a piece of land to increase his farm. In ten years, he plans to buy a pick-up truck for transporting his produce.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers, animal feeds and a sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy another dairy cow to increase his milk production

loans.name: Karanja

texts.en:
Karanja is a married man with four children. He has been selling firewood for five years.

As a member of the Githiga Upright self-help group of Faulu Kenya, Karanja has been guaranteed a loan of 20,000 KES to add to his stock of firewood. He believes that his income will increase with additional stock.

Karanja says that his life and family situation have changed positively since joining Faulu. He hopes to enlarge his business in the future.

loans.use: To add to his stock of firewood

loans.name: Believer Group

texts.en: Yamah V., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Believer." She is 23 years old, married, and has two children aged one and seven years old. She was only able to attend school through 3rd grade due to lack of financial support. For three years, she has been selling biscuits, peanuts, bread, candy, milk, juice etc. in Chief Compound Community in Gbarnga, central Liberia. She plans to use her 4,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 20,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more biscuits, peanuts, bread, candy, milk, juice etc. She describes herself as easy-going. Her dream is to improve her business and educate her children.
